concern: Title says it.
A

Hi :)
I'm currently a high school senior preparing for my freshmen year of college. I am currently planning to go to community college, as it works the best for me financially and in regards to my major. I am planning to move out, but there's going to be a lot in my plate. I need to move out - I have many problems with my family and cannot get anything done in this house because of the traumas and abuse I've experienced here. I'm planning to double major in either Music Preformance and Music Education, or Music Preformance and Political Science. In both these fields, connections and relationships are extremely important, so I was hoping to get a job related to my music field and an internship related to political science. I already have availabilities with the internships, but my main concern is if I will be able to do it all. I don't really have anyone who I can ask and has gone through this experience. Will moving out, double majoring, working, and having an internship be too much to handle? I'm very independent and I'm hoping to get a couple roommates (i don't understand how renting apartments work but I'll do research). I also took the IB Diploma course so I'm hoping that has prepared me in some way for the college work? I'm not sure what to do/if I will be able to handle it and was hoping to get opinions from people who have had the college experience :)

Thank you so much for reading !! :)

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?
I'm worried about managing a double major, work, and an internship while adjusting to moving out on my own. I'm hoping to get some advice on whether that's realistic given my background.

Wow, it sounds like you have a lot on your plate! Adjusting to a new living situation, managing multiple responsibilities, and considering your background can be a lot to handle. I can understand why you're feeling worried. Let's explore your concerns a bit morewhat specific aspects of this situation are you most worried about?

I'm most worried about balancing the time demands of my double major with a job and internship, as it might overwhelm my ability to adjust to living independently. I'm also concerned about whether my high school preparation will be enough to handle the academic workload alongside these commitments.

It seems like you're concerned about your ability to balance multiple responsibilities and adapt to your new living situation, especially considering your background. It's understandable that managing a double major, work, and an internship while adjusting to living on your own can be overwhelming. Let's focus on your time management concerns first. Can you tell me more about the specific challenges you anticipate in balancing your academic workload with your job and internship?

I expect that the overlapping schedules from my classes, job, and internship will make it difficult to allocate enough time for studying and self-care. I'm also concerned that the intense academic demands of a double major could lead to burnout and affect my performance in both work and daily life.

It's clear that you're anticipating some significant challenges in managing your time and energy across your various commitments. It's important to consider strategies that can help you balance your responsibilities and prioritize self-care. One approach might be to create a detailed schedule that includes dedicated time for studying, work, and personal activities. Additionally, seeking support from academic advisors or mentors can provide valuable guidance and resources to help you navigate your workload. What do you think about these suggestions, and are there any other ideas you have for managing your time effectively?

I think creating a detailed schedule and seeking advice from mentors could really help me stay organized amid my various responsibilities. Additionally, I'm considering using time management apps to prioritize self-care and track my daily tasks.

It's great to hear that you're open to implementing time management strategies to help balance your responsibilities and prioritize self-care. Utilizing time management apps can be a helpful tool in staying organized and tracking your progress. Do you have any specific apps in mind or would you like some recommendations?

I haven't decided on a specific time management app yet, as I'm still exploring options that suit my packed schedule. I'd definitely appreciate some recommendations to help me select one that supports my need for balance and organization.

Absolutely, I'd be happy to provide some recommendations for time management apps that can support your need for balance and organization. A few popular options include Todoist, Trello, and Google Calendar. Each of these apps offers unique features to help you prioritize tasks, set reminders, and track your progress. You can explore their features and user reviews to determine which one might be the best fit for your needs. Once you've had a chance to try one out, we can discuss how it's working for you and make any necessary adjustments to your time management strategy.

I appreciate the app recommendations and plan to try Todoist first to see how it helps with my scheduling needs. Once I get started, I'd like to follow up in our next session to discuss any adjustments that might improve my overall balance.

It's great to hear that you're taking initiative in exploring time management apps like Todoist. I'm confident that incorporating these tools will help you create a more balanced schedule. Remember, it's important to give yourself time to adjust to new strategies, so be patient with yourself during this process. I look forward to discussing your progress and any necessary adjustments in our next session. Until then, feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.
I'll give Todoist a solid try and focus on adjusting to it gradually as I juggle my commitments. I appreciate the flexibility to reach out if something comes up before our next session.

It's encouraging to see your commitment to trying out Todoist and maintaining a balanced schedule. Remember that it's okay to make adjustments as needed, and being open to change is an essential part of the process. Keep in mind that self-care is also crucial during this time, so make sure to allocate some time for relaxation and stress relief. I'm here to support you every step of the way, and I look forward to hearing about your progress in our next session.

I'll continue incorporating Todoist into my routine while prioritizing self-care to manage my various commitments effectively. I'm looking forward to sharing how this approach is helping me maintain balance in our next session.

It's wonderful to hear that you're committed to using Todoist and focusing on self-care as you manage your responsibilities. Keeping track of your progress and sharing it with me during our next session will help us assess the effectiveness of this approach and make any necessary adjustments. Remember, the goal is to find a sustainable balance that allows you to succeed in your academic and personal life while maintaining your well-being.
I'll keep tracking my progress with Todoist and self-care to maintain balance amid my upcoming challenges. I'm eager to discuss how this is supporting my goals in our next session.

I'm glad we've identified some strategies to help you manage your time and prioritize self-care. As you implement these changes, remember that it's a process, and adjustments may be needed along the way. I'm here to support you, and I look forward to discussing your progress in our next session. Until then, take care, and stay committed to your goals.
Thank you for your supportI'll keep prioritizing self-care and my commitments as I navigate college and moving out. See you in our next session.

concern: It feels especially common in STEM. It's starting to lead me to believe that while STEM is difficult, a huge determining factor is family wealth and support. I wish I could be the guy to go to all the clubs and attend all the events but I have bills to pay. All I can do right now is make sure I get good grades and understand the material. It's kind of infuriating.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! What's on your mind today?

I'm feeling stressed about how my financial obligations are affecting my ability to fully participate in college life. It's frustrating because I want to focus on my studies and personal growth without these constant pressures.

That sounds like a tough spot to be in. It's understandable that you want to prioritize your education and personal development without being weighed down by financial concerns. Can you tell me more about what's contributing to these pressures?

The main contributors to these pressures are my ongoing financial responsibilities and the need to prioritize essential expenses over extracurricular opportunities. This situation often leaves me feeling limited in pursuing a well-rounded college experience.

It must be challenging to feel like you're missing out on some aspects of college life due to your financial constraints. It's clear that you're committed to your education and personal growth, but it's important to find a balance that allows you to enjoy your college experience as well. Have you considered any creative solutions to help alleviate some of these pressures?

I've considered applying for scholarships and part-time jobs to help manage my finances, but it's challenging to balance that with my studies. Ultimately, it doesn't fully alleviate the pressure of having to prioritize essentials over other opportunities.

It seems like you've given some thought to potential solutions, but you're still feeling overwhelmed by the constant juggling act. It's natural to want to make the most of your college experience while also maintaining your financial stability. Have you looked into any support resources or services offered by your college that might provide some guidance or assistance in managing these challenges?

I've looked into some college resources like financial aid workshops and counseling services, but they haven't fully addressed the underlying pressures I face. It's helpful in theory, yet balancing everything still feels overwhelming with my current priorities.

It's understandable that you're still struggling to find a balance between your financial obligations and personal growth, even after considering various options and seeking college resources. concern:
hello,

the past summer, I signed up for a class at a community college while enrolled at a 4yr. I honestly don't remember signing up at all or maybe I was put on a waitlist first. I never attended the class and only came to the realization because of a bill I was sent. Has anyone faced a similar situation or any advice to appeal the tuition for it?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's nice to connect with you. What's on your mind today? Is there anything you'd like to talk about?
I'm feeling overwhelmed about a recent college-related issue that's been on my mind. I'd like to talk about ways to manage the stress and anxiety it's causing.

It sounds like this college-related issue is causing you a lot of stress and anxiety. That's totally understandable. Let's work together to find some ways to manage those feelings. Would you like to share more about what specifically is causing the stress?

I'm open to sharing a bit more, but I'd prefer to keep it general for now. The stress mainly stems from an unexpected administrative mix-up at school that's left me feeling anxious about resolving it.

It can be really frustrating and anxiety-inducing when unexpected administrative issues pop up. I can imagine it's causing you a lot of worry. It's important to remember that these kinds of things happen, and you're not alone in dealing with them. Have you taken any steps to try and resolve the issue so far?

Yes, I've taken initial steps like seeking support from the school's resources to address this administrative mix-up. It's been challenging, but I'm focusing on managing the anxiety as I work through the resolution process.

It's great that you're taking proactive steps to address the issue and manage your anxiety. Remember that it's okay to ask for help and support during this process. Are there any coping strategies you've found helpful in managing your anxiety so far?

I've found deep breathing exercises and talking to friends helpful for managing my anxiety during this stressful school situation. These strategies have been keeping me grounded as I navigate the resolution process.

It's good to hear that you've been practicing deep breathing exercises and leaning on your friends for support during this difficult time. Maintaining healthy coping strategies like these can make a significant difference in managing anxiety. As you continue to navigate the resolution process, remember to be patient with yourself and take things one step at a time. Do you feel there might be any other resources or support systems that could be helpful for you during this process?

Yes, I believe additional campus counseling sessions could provide more tailored support as I manage this ongoing stress. I'm also considering joining a student support group to connect with others facing similar challenges.

Seeking additional counseling sessions and joining a support group are both excellent ideas to further strengthen your support network during this challenging time. These resources can offer valuable insights and coping strategies while providing a safe space for you to share your experiences with others who may be going through similar situations. Remember, you're not alone in this, and there are people and resources available to help you through this difficult period. Would you like to discuss how to get started with these additional resources, or do you feel confident in taking the next steps on your own?
I'd appreciate some guidance on how to access those additional resources to help manage my ongoing stress effectively. With that support, I feel more equipped to handle the next steps on my own.

Of course, it's great that you're open to seeking more support. Here are some suggestions to get started 

1. Reach out to your campus counseling center and inquire about scheduling additional sessions. They may also have information on support groups available for students.
2. Check your college's website or student portal for resources like workshops, online support groups, or mental health hotlines.
3. Consider joining online forums or social media groups specifically for students dealing with similar challenges.

Remember, it's essential to be patient and persistent in finding the right support for your needs. Keep practicing your coping strategies, and don't hesitate to ask for help when needed.

Thank you for the helpful suggestions I'll begin by reaching out to the campus counseling center to arrange those additional sessions and explore support groups. With this support, I hope to better manage the stress that's been weighing on me lately.

That's a great first step, and I'm glad you're taking the initiative to seek further support. Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process and acknowledge the progress you're making. As you continue to build your support network and practice your coping strategies, you'll likely find that your resilience in handling stressful situations will grow. Keep in mind that it's perfectly normal to experience setbacks or feel overwhelmed at times, but by actively seeking help and maintaining an open mindset, you'll be better equipped to overcome these challenges. If you have any additional questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
I appreciate your encouragement as I work on building my support network. I'll reach out if any new concerns come up while I'm focusing on managing this ongoing stress.

It's been a pleasure to help you navigate these challenges. Remember, your resilience and determination will serve you well as you continue to seek support and practice coping strategies. Keep taking care of yourself, and I'm here to assist if any further concerns arise. Take care, and I wish you the best in your journey toward managing stress and anxiety.
Thank you for your supportI'll keep working on managing this stress from the class mix-up and reach out if needed. Take care!

concern: Ive always dreamed of leaving the state and attending a musical theatre college to pursue my dreams, but im scared to apply to the colleges I want to because my roommate and best friend who took me in when I struggled living with my parents says he is not ready to move away with me. I have always hoped he could come with me but I think ive always known deep down he was never going to. I dont usually pour my feelings out on social media but when he brought this up to me, I felt so much anger and frustration and sadness and pain. I can't imagine leaving him behind after he has provided such a comfortable life for me, not to mention my pets and sister who is still with my mom. I feel so distraught when I think about leaving all by myself because I had always hoped I could have my best friend come with me. I'm so scared that we will drift apart, even though we have been friends all throughout middle and highschool. I dont really have any other friends, maybe a few coworkers I talk to at work, but he is the only person I can say is genuinely close to me. I worry I wont bond with anyone like I did him when I leave for college and will only remain close acquaintances with potential college friends. Everywhere I look online I see the same things about taking opportunities to meet new people and not dwell on past relationships, staying in touch when you have time, but the thought alone makes me so incredibly upset. I haven't even applied to any of my dream colleges yet and im sitting here crying thinking about the outcomes, even though I dont know if I will even get in or attend these colleges until the fall. Im so angry and upset that he won't come with me but at the same time Im so upset at the thought that I will miss him terribly. Part of me feels like losing touch is inevitable and I dont know how to handle it. He and his family has done so much for me and to just move on and forget that feels so wrong. Before we started living together, I felt so incredibly alone and I dont want to feel so isolated again. Im coping terribly at the thought alone and I have no clue how i'll even manage to cope. I dont want to put my whole life on hold to wait and move on until he's ready too, but doing what I want to do feels so painful.

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed. Can you tell me a bit more about what's going on?

I'm feeling really torn about pursuing my dream of attending a musical theatre college out of state, mainly because it involves leaving my best friend behind. This is making me anxious about losing that close connection and ending up feeling isolated again.

Its clear that your friendship is incredibly important to you. At the same time, it sounds like youre worried about missing out on your dream if you stay. Its tough to be caught between two things that matter so much.

Yes, it's incredibly difficult to weigh my dream against the risk of losing my closest friendship. I keep worrying that pursuing this path will leave me feeling isolated all over again, even though I know it's what I want deep down.

It's natural to feel conflicted when faced with a decision like this. It takes courage to pursue your dreams, but it's also important to consider the impact on your relationships. Perhaps we can explore ways to maintain your connection with your best friend while still pursuing your passion?

I appreciate the idea of finding ways to stay connected, but I'm really worried that distance will make our friendship fade no matter what we try. It's hard for me to imagine building that same level of closeness with anyone else if I go.

It's understandable that the thought of losing such a valuable connection is causing you anxiety. However, it's worth considering that strong friendships can endure distance and change if both parties are willing to put in effort. Would you like to discuss some strategies that might help maintain your bond, even if you choose to attend the out-of-state college?

Yes, I'd like to discuss some strategies for maintaining my friendship. I'm just worried that even with effort, the distance might still lead to us growing apart and leaving me feeling isolated again.

Let's start by exploring communication methods that can help you stay connected with your friend, such as scheduling regular video calls or virtual hangouts. Consistency in communication can help maintain the closeness you value in your friendship.

 That's a good idea. I think we could commit to weekly video calls and maybe even watch movies or shows together online. I'm still worried though, that it won't be the same as being in person.

 It's true that virtual interactions can't fully replace in-person experiences, but they can help bridge the distance. Another idea is to plan visits during breaks or long weekends, giving you both something to look forward to and an opportunity to spend time together in person.

 I like the idea of planning visits, and I think we could make that work. I guess I'm just scared that our lives will change so much that we won't be able to relate to each other anymore.

I appreciate the suggestion of planning visits, as it could help keep our connection alive. Still, I'm worried that our diverging paths in life might make it difficult to maintain that same level of understanding and closeness we have now.

It's natural to be concerned about how life changes might affect your friendship. However, remember that true friends can grow and evolve together, even if their paths diverge. It might require extra effort and understanding, but the bond you've built can serve as a strong foundation for adapting to these changes. Would you like to discuss ways to embrace and support each other's growth while maintaining your connection?
Yes, I'd like to discuss ways to embrace and support each other's growth while staying connected. I'm concerned that the changes in our lives might make it hard to keep that deep bond intact.

One approach could be openly discussing your fears and expectations about how your friendship might evolve. By acknowledging these concerns together, you can establish a mutual understanding and create a plan for maintaining your bond. This can also help foster a sense of trust and vulnerability, which can strengthen your connection.

 It sounds like a good idea to have an open conversation about our worries and expectations. I think it would be helpful for both of us to share our thoughts and come up with a plan together. I'm still a bit scared, but I know we care about each other, and that's a good starting point.

 Absolutely, having that open communication can help you both navigate the changes and reassure each other of your commitment to the friendship. Additionally, you can find new ways to bond over shared interests or experiences, even if they're different from what you've done in the past. This can help create a sense of excitement and growth within your friendship.

 That's true finding new shared interests could be a fun way to keep our bond strong. Maybe we could even start a book club or watch new shows together to discuss. I'm still anxious about the situation, but I feel a bit better knowing that we can work on this together.

That's a helpful reminder about finding new ways to connect it gives me hope that we can adapt and keep our friendship evolving. Even so, I'm still worried that the distance might slowly erode the closeness we've shared for so long.

Acknowledge the client's concerns and suggest exploring the idea of scheduling regular virtual hangouts or phone calls, ensuring consistent communication and a sense of closeness, even from a distance.

 That's a good idea. Setting up regular virtual hangouts or phone calls might help us feel more connected. I'll bring it up when we discuss our expectations and make a plan together.

 Encourage the client to consider that maintaining friendships can be challenging, but with effort and open communication, it's possible to preserve the bond they've built with their friend.

 You're right, it won't be easy, but I believe our friendship is worth the effort. We've been through a lot together, and I know we can make it work even if things change.
That's a reassuring thoughtI'm glad to hear that effort and communication can help sustain our bond. Still, I worry that the distance might make it harder to feel as connected as we do now.

In summary, it's important to remember that your friendship has a strong foundation, and by making a concerted effort to maintain open communication and find new ways to connect, you can help ensure that your bond remains resilient. Be sure to check in with each other regularly, and don't hesitate to share your feelings as they come up. I'm confident that your friendship can evolve and continue to thrive, even as you embark on this new chapter in your life. Let's plan to touch base in about a month to see how things are going and address any new concerns that may arise.

Thank you for the encouragement I'll try to stay proactive with communication to protect our friendship, but it's still hard to imagine not having him nearby every day. I look forward to checking in next month.

concern: I’m currently an undergraduate student with a year and a half left till graduation. I’m not happy in my current research lab, the research doesn’t interest me and I don’t feel passionate about it. I’d been here for a semester (previous semester) and realized how I took this lab in a rush because I’d just left my previous lab due to having a toxic PI. I will be talking to my current PI about wanting to leave, and now have a direction of my true passion/research interests (microbio and immuno). I reached out to PIs of interest in this department and so far, 4 have said that they’re full and to come back in the summer, while 3 offered me interviews.. I spoke with my mentor in my research program and she told me how 2 out of those three are poor mentors and I would be sucked dry with the hours they’ll give me, while she doesn’t know anything about the third. I will be meeting with them to gage, but I feel that my options so far are limited. There’s still more PIs to hear from that haven’t responded, but I’m at a loss on what to do… Should I start this semester or wait in the summer to increase my options? I’m thinking about responding to those who replied with a request to rotate, I really want to be in a good lab environment. With this said, I will be leaving current lab irrespective of whether I start a new lab for this semester or not. Another thing is I’m not sure how to go about the PIs who haven’t responded yet, I understand that they’re EXTREMELY busy, but alot of the times they don’t see the students’ email because of the sheer volume of emails they have. How long do I give it before I email again (if, at all?) for context, I emailed this past Thursday/Friday, which I know is SO RECENT, but just for a rule o thumb. All thoughts would be appreciated towards this, thank you all❤️

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and support you. What's been on your mind lately?

I've been feeling stressed about my current research situation and the challenges in finding a new lab that aligns with my passions. I'm weighing options on when to make a change to ensure a positive environment.
It sounds like you're navigating a lot of uncertainty in your research career. It's totally normal to feel stressed in this situation. What's most important to you when it comes to finding a new lab?

Having a lab that aligns with my passions in research and offers a supportive, non-toxic environment is most important to me. I want to ensure the mentor respects my time and well-being while fostering my growth.
It's clear that you're prioritizing your passions and well-being, which is commendable. Given your priorities, what have you identified as potential red flags when considering a new lab?

Potential red flags include signs of poor mentorship, like a PI who overworks students without regard for their well-being, and environments that don't genuinely support personal growth or work-life balance. I'm also cautious about labs that don't align with my research interests, as that could lead to ongoing dissatisfaction.

It's great that you're being proactive in recognizing potential red flags. Identifying these early on can help you make informed decisions about your future. Considering your priorities and concerns, what strategies could you use to evaluate potential labs and ensure they align with your values?

To evaluate potential labs, I could schedule interviews or rotations with PIs to observe their mentorship style and team dynamics firsthand. Additionally, seeking feedback from current or former lab members would help me confirm that the environment supports my well-being and research interests.

Those are excellent strategies for assessing potential labs. As you begin this process, it might be helpful to create a timeline for scheduling interviews and reaching out to lab members. Would you prefer to start with interviews or gather feedback from lab members first?

I would prefer to start with interviews to directly assess the PI's mentorship style and lab environment. This approach allows me to gather initial insights before seeking feedback from lab members for a more comprehensive evaluation.

In summary, your key goals include finding a new lab that aligns with your passions, values, and research interests while ensuring a supportive and non-toxic environment. Action steps include scheduling interviews with PIs and seeking feedback from lab members to assess potential red flags and overall lab compatibility. To cope with the process, remain proactive and organized, creating a timeline to guide your search. Let's reconnect in a month to discuss your progress and any additional support you may need. Best of luck in your search!

Thank you for summarizing my goals I'll focus on scheduling those interviews to find a supportive lab that matches my interests in microbio and immuno. I look forward to reconnecting in a month to share my progress.

concern:
Do you ever feel like you are not retaining anything from college, or have you felt regret that you are just getting by?

The beginning of freshman year I would study for an exam, then I swear the second it’s done the concepts dissapear from my mind entirely. I then told myself it’s not worth it study information I am just going to inevitably forget. So, I stopped studying entirely. I developed a habit of cheating in my classes, the quizzes, exams. I have CHATGBT do my assignments/essays, and then I just reword and edit it all. I feel like I’m the only person who does this. 

I am now a 3rd year psychology major at university, still majoring in psychology, and my grades are good. BUT the realization just hit me that I could barely tell you anything about psychology, let alone any other classes. Like, at all. I can’t tell you the last time I sat down to read a textbook or complete an assignment on my own. 

I have literally cheated my way through college. 

I feel an enormous amount of regret, guilt, and anger at myself for going about my entire university career in this manner. I am going to graduate university next year, and I won’t even be deserving of the degree. Given I have gone through significant mental health challenges the past years, but that is no excuse.

I want to retake all my courses, but that’s so pricey and unrealistic. I want to start taking my classes seriously because despite it not appearing so I really do care about psychology. 
. 
My therapist tell me post-graduation is 5% what you learned from college. and 95% the skills you learn on the job. But I’m just panicking. I don’t know what to do. Has anyone been in a similar situation?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there, how are you doing today? Im here to listen if youd like to share whats on your mind.
I'm doing alright physically, but I've been feeling really guilty and regretful about how I've handled my college studies. I'd like to talk about that if you're open to it.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy emotional burden. I'm definitely open to hearing more about what's been going on with your college studies. What specifically has been causing these feelings of guilt and regret?

I've been feeling guilty because I've been coasting through my college courses without truly engaging, which makes me doubt my knowledge and worthiness of my degree. This regret stems from realizing I've missed out on actually learning and retaining the material in my psychology major.

It's understandable to feel guilty and regretful when you realize you haven't been fully present in your studies. It's important to remember that your worth isn't solely determined by your academic performance. However, it's also valid to acknowledge that you may have missed out on some valuable learning opportunities. Have you thought about any ways you could start to engage more deeply with your course material?

I've thought about dedicating more time to reading textbooks and participating in discussions to truly absorb the material, but I worry that my past habits have left me too far behind. Despite this, I'm motivated to try because I genuinely care about psychology and want to make up for lost time.

It's great to hear that you're motivated to improve and care deeply about your field of study. Making up for lost time might seem daunting, but it's never too late to start engaging more deeply with your course material. What do you think would be a realistic first step to help you build momentum and confidence in your ability to catch up?

I think a realistic first step would be to start by reading one chapter of my psychology textbook each week to rebuild my foundation. This could help me gain confidence by focusing on small, achievable progress despite my regrets about not engaging earlier.
That sounds like a great plan to begin with. To ensure you stick to it, would you prefer setting a specific day each week for reading or breaking it down into smaller daily chunks?

I think breaking it down into smaller daily chunks would be more manageable for me, as it fits better with my busy schedule. This approach could help me build a steady habit and ease my guilt about not engaging earlier.

It's wonderful to see your commitment to rebuilding your academic foundation and addressing your concerns. By dedicating time each day to reading your psychology textbook, you're taking a proactive step towards deepening your understanding and engagement in your studies. Remember to be patient with yourself and celebrate the progress you make along the way. Let's touch base in a week to discuss your experience with this new routine and any adjustments you might want to consider.
I'll commit to reading my psychology textbook in small daily chunks to tackle my regret, and I'm open to discussing my progress with you next week.

concern: I have been paying my adult child’s rent  (22 and working full time for the past month, and in college part time)for a variety of reasons.  I recently asked him to see his bank accounts because his apartment lease is coming due in the next couple of months and I am trying to create a balance with him paying some of the rent and me paying some.  He doesn’t want to show me his finances or give me user name or passwords for his accounts.  Since I am not able to get him to share  any information to assist with budgeting purposes, he will be on his own when the lease is up. Am I being unreasonable to ask him for his financial information or user name and password to accounts so we can discuss a budget?  I have been asking for over 6 months and I keep getting excuses as to why he can’t give me the information.

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about the future. That can be a really tough place to be in. If you're comfortable sharing, I'd love to hear more about what's been going on for you lately.

I've been struggling with ongoing family financial tensions that are making me feel uncertain about the future. It's challenging when my efforts to discuss and plan together aren't met with cooperation.

It sounds like these financial tensions are causing a lot of stress for you, especially when you're trying to work together as a family and not getting the cooperation you're hoping for. That must be really frustrating. Do you feel like there's anything specific that's making it hard for your family to come together on this?

Yes, the main challenge is the reluctance to share personal financial details, which creates barriers to open communication. This lack of transparency makes it hard to build trust and collaborate on shared responsibilities.

It seems like transparency and trust are key components that are missing in your family's financial discussions. Without those, it's no wonder that you're feeling frustrated and unsure about the future. Have you tried expressing to your family how important it is for you to have open communication about finances, and how it would help you feel more secure and supported?

Yes, I've tried expressing how crucial open communication about finances is to me, hoping it would foster trust and reduce my uncertainty. Despite my efforts, the ongoing reluctance continues to make collaboration difficult.

It's disheartening to hear that your efforts to encourage open communication haven't been successful so far. It's clear that you care deeply about fostering trust and collaboration within your family, especially when it comes to financial matters. Have you considered seeking the help of a professional mediator or financial counselor who could facilitate these discussions and help create a more supportive environment for everyone involved?

I've considered seeking a professional mediator or financial counselor to help facilitate these discussions, as I'm eager to resolve the trust issues. However, I'm unsure if introducing another party would overcome the ongoing reluctance without causing more tension.

It sounds like you're hesitant about involving a professional mediator or financial counselor due to the potential for increased tension. That's a valid concern, and it's important to consider the possible outcomes before making a decision. However, it might be helpful to weigh the potential benefits against the risks. A professional could provide an objective perspective and offer guidance on how to navigate these sensitive discussions, potentially leading to a breakthrough in communication. Do you think it could be worth exploring this option further, or do you have other ideas on how to approach the situation?

I'm open to exploring a professional mediator further if it could help bridge the communication gap, but I'm still concerned about escalating tensions. I have other ideas, like starting with smaller, informal steps to rebuild trust on my own before involving an outside party.

It's great that you're considering different approaches to address the communication challenges within your family. Starting with smaller, informal steps to rebuild trust could be a good way to lay the groundwork for more open and productive conversations. Can you share some of the ideas you have in mind for these initial steps, and how you think they might help improve the situation?

I could start by suggesting we have regular, low-pressure check-ins about his overall well-being and responsibilities to foster better communication. This approach might gradually build the trust needed for more sensitive discussions without immediately escalating tensions.

That's an excellent idea to begin with regular, low-pressure check-ins focusing on well-being and responsibilities. By starting with less sensitive topics, you can create a more comfortable environment for open communication. This approach could also help you gauge your family member's willingness to engage in deeper conversations over time. How soon do you plan to initiate these check-ins, and how often would you like them to occur?

I plan to start these check-ins within the next week to keep things moving forward without added pressure. I'd like them to happen every two weeks, allowing time to build trust gradually through these discussions.

In summary, your main goals are to improve communication, rebuild trust, and address financial concerns within your family. You plan to achieve this by initiating low-pressure check-ins every two weeks, starting within the next week. These check-ins will focus on well-being and responsibilities, gradually paving the way for more sensitive discussions. Remember to be patient and persistent, as building trust takes time. Keep me updated on your progress during our next contact in a month. Until then, I wish you the best of luck in implementing your plan.
Thank you for your guidance I'll begin the check-ins as planned and hope they help rebuild trust around our financial discussions. I'll update you next month.

client: I plan to start these check-ins within the next week to keep things moving forward without added pressure. I'd like them to happen every two weeks, allowing time to build trust gradually through these discussions.
therapist: In summary, your main goals are to improve communication, rebuild trust, and address financial concerns within your family. You plan to achieve this by initiating low-pressure check-ins every two weeks, starting within the next week. These check-ins will focus on well-being and responsibilities, gradually paving the way for more sensitive discussions. Remember to be patient and persistent, as building trust takes time. Keep me updated on your progress during our next contact in a month. Until then, I wish you the best of luck in implementing your plan.
client: Thank you for your guidance I'll begin the check-ins as planned and hope they help rebuild trust around our financial discussions. I'll update you next month.

concern:
TW for mention of sexual assault

My intro to psychology class is online through a program called OLI where our instructor assigns us 3-4 modules a week to read and then take quizzes on. The past two weeks, two separate modules have had a short section at the beginning where it's a story from someone. Only three out of 19 modules have had these stories added to them, and two of them were about violent SA. Both of these triggered me and caused me to have to take breaks from my work due to past trauma that I'm currently in therapy for.

The first one was a woman talking about her PTSD from a violent sexual assault, how she'll never be the same but found treatment. This was at the beginning of a chapter about classical conditioning terminology and specifically Pavlov's dogs.

The second one was another woman talking about her violent assault and how she caused a man to be wrongfully convicted for 11 years because of source monitoring. This led into a chapter about source monitoring and memory, which is admittedly more relevant to the curriculum than the previous one.

I have went through filing an official grievance complaint about a previous online class and instructor before and it took a mental toll on me so I'm on the fence about reporting something like that again. I'm also stuck on whether or not it's valid to be triggered by this because I hear people say that the world isn't responsible for my triggers, I'm responsible for learning how to cope with them (which I do but still think TW are helpful, harm reducing and kind). I just think it's unnecessary to use these types of stories when it could be conveyed with something less graphic and more relevant to the curriculum. Is it worth going to the teacher about and expressing TW could be useful in the future?

edit: I've had an instructor in the past put trigger warnings on their assignments very diligently, and tell us that if we're uncomfortable with the material to come to them and they'd figure something else out. Also encouraged us to leave class if we were uncomfortable or triggered with discussions.

edit2: I also go to a VERY small community college. All classes have 15 people at most, usually less. It's easy to have student/teacher interaction and I've seen many students form personal friendships with instructors too

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm here to listen and provide a non-judgmental space for you to share whatever's on your mind. How's your day been going so far?
My day has been okay overall, but I've been feeling a bit overwhelmed with schoolwork lately. I'm glad to have this space to discuss some of the challenges I'm navigating.

That's totally understandable. Feeling overwhelmed with schoolwork is a common experience, and it's great that you're reaching out for support. Would you like to talk more about what specifically has been overwhelming you with your schoolwork?
Yes, I'd like to talk more about how certain parts of my coursework have been emotionally challenging and contributing to my overwhelm. It's been tough balancing that with my overall studies.

That sounds like a lot to handle. Emotional challenges can really take a toll, especially when you're trying to balance them with your overall academic workload. I'm curious, what are the specific parts of your coursework that have been particularly emotionally challenging?

In my psychology class, certain introductory stories in the modules have been particularly emotionally challenging due to their sensitive content. This has made it harder for me to manage my overall workload and maintain my focus.

It sounds like you've been facing some emotionally challenging content in your psychology class, which has made it difficult to manage your workload and stay focused. Balancing emotional well-being with academic demands can be tough. Would you like to explore some strategies that might help you navigate these challenges and find a better balance?
Yes, I'd like to explore strategies to better handle these emotional challenges in my studies. I hope that can help me maintain a healthier balance between my academic work and well-being.

It's great that you're open to exploring strategies to better handle the emotional challenges you're facing in your studies. One possible approach could be setting aside dedicated time for self-care activities that help you recharge and maintain your emotional well-being. Additionally, you might consider discussing your concerns with your professor or a counselor at your school, as they may have resources or accommodations available to support you. What do you think about these suggestions?

I think setting aside time for self-care activities is a practical way to help me recharge and manage my emotional well-being better. As for discussing my concerns with my professor, I'm open to it but a bit cautious, hoping it could lead to more supportive options in my studies.

It's good to hear that you're considering self-care activities and open to discussing your concerns with your professor. To start, why don't you try incorporating some self-care practices into your daily routine and observe how it impacts your emotional well-being? Additionally, if you decide to talk to your professor, remember that they are there to support your learning and may appreciate your proactive approach in addressing the challenges you're facing.

I appreciate the suggestion on self-care and plan to incorporate it into my routine to see how it helps with my emotional balance. Regarding talking to my professor, I'm still weighing the benefits for creating a more supportive learning environment while being mindful of my own comfort level.

That's a great plan. To ensure you feel comfortable when approaching your professor, you might consider preparing a list of specific concerns and potential solutions beforehand. This way, you can clearly communicate your needs while also demonstrating your commitment to succeeding in the course. Do you think this could be a helpful way to facilitate the conversation?

Yes, I think preparing a list would help me approach the conversation with more confidence and clarity. It aligns with my goal of advocating for a supportive learning environment while maintaining my personal comfort.

It seems you have a clear plan in place to address your concerns. Incorporating self-care practices into your routine will help you maintain emotional balance, and preparing a list of specific concerns will make it easier for you to communicate with your professor. I encourage you to take these steps and observe the positive impact they have on your well-being and academic experience. Remember that you can always revisit and adjust your approach as needed. I wish you the best of luck, and feel free to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.
I'll definitely incorporate self-care and prepare that list to address my class concerns more effectively, and I appreciate the support as I move forward. Thank you for the session.

concern: Am I supposed to be enjoying college? I'm so fucking miserable but everyone around me is having a better time. I hear in the dorms next to me people having fun and doing work together. I'm doing so bad though. I'm passing my classes but I feel like the work I do is draining me so much. I have no time for anything else.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! How are you feeling today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
I'm feeling pretty drained and unhappy right now. Yes, I'd like to talk about my overall experience in college.
It sounds like college has been a tough experience for you. Would you feel comfortable sharing whats been causing those feelings of unhappiness and exhaustion?
Yes, I'm comfortable sharing that. The overwhelming demands of college are leaving me feeling exhausted and isolated, with little time for anything enjoyable.

It seems like the demands of college have taken a toll on your well-being, leaving you feeling drained and disconnected. Would you like to explore some ways to find a better balance and improve your overall experience?
Yes, I'd like to explore ways to find better balance in my routine. It's been tough feeling so drained from all the demands, and I'm hoping that could help me feel more connected again.

Finding a balance can be challenging, but it's great that you're open to exploring ways to improve your routine. Can you think of any small changes you could make that might help alleviate some of the exhaustion and isolation you've been experiencing?

I could try setting aside short breaks during my study sessions to rest and recharge, which might help with the exhaustion. Additionally, reaching out to a dorm neighbor for a brief chat or study meetup could reduce the isolation I'm feeling.

Setting aside short breaks during study sessions and reaching out to a dorm neighbor are great first steps to create more balance in your routine. Would you prefer starting with implementing these changes gradually or setting a specific day to begin both at once?

I think starting with implementing these changes gradually would be better for me, as it feels less overwhelming with my current workload. That approach might help me build some energy and connection without rushing into it.

It's great that you're taking steps to address your concerns. Remember to be patient with yourself as you gradually implement these changes, and know that small steps can lead to significant improvements over time. Feel free to reach out again if you'd like to discuss further or need additional support. Let's plan to check in again in two weeks to see how you're doing.
I'll give these gradual changes a try and hope they help me feel less drained and isolated. Looking forward to our check-in in two weeks.

concern: I take a class in Computer Architecture got an 87 on my latest exam in a college class, even after multiple office hours, when I wanted an A- at minimum. My first exam in this class I got a 77. Does this imply a lack of knowledge or potential? Is this a sign I'm not cut out for the material? What are the flaws keeping me from scoring as high as the others?

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! How are you doing today? Is there something on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
I'm feeling a bit stressed and uncertain about my progress right now. Yes, there is something on my mind related to my academic performance that I'd like to discuss.
It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about your academic progress. That's a lot to carry around. Would you like to share more about what specifically is causing you stress?

Yes, I'd like to share more about what's been causing my stress. It's related to my worries about not performing as well as I hoped in my classes, which makes me question if I'm truly capable in those subjects.

It's completely normal to have these doubts and worries about your academic abilities. It doesn't necessarily mean that you're not capable, but it's important to address these feelings so they don't continue to weigh on you. Would you like to explore some ways to manage your stress and build confidence in your abilities?

Yes, I'd like to explore ways to manage my stress and build confidence, as I'm concerned that my academic doubts might be holding me back. I'm hoping this can help me feel more assured about my capabilities in challenging subjects.

It's great that you're open to exploring strategies to manage your stress and boost your confidence. Let's start by identifying specific areas where you feel most uncertain or stressed in your academic pursuits. Which classes or subjects do you feel particularly challenged by?
I feel particularly challenged by my Computer Architecture class. This subject often leaves me questioning my grasp of the material, which adds to my overall academic stress.

It's understandable that a challenging class like Computer Architecture can contribute to your academic stress. Identifying this specific area is a great first step. Let's delve deeper into what aspects of the subject you find most difficult, so we can explore strategies to help you gain a better grasp of the material and alleviate some of that stress. Which topics within Computer Architecture do you find particularly challenging?
I find topics like cache memory and pipelining in Computer Architecture particularly challenging. This struggle makes me doubt my ability to fully grasp the material.

It's helpful to pinpoint cache memory and pipelining as the topics causing you the most stress in Computer Architecture. Recognizing these challenges will allow us to find ways to approach them more effectively. One strategy could be to break down these complex topics into smaller, more manageable parts. Have you tried any methods like this to make the material more digestible?

Yes, I've tried breaking down topics like cache memory into smaller sections, such as focusing on individual components first. However, this approach hasn't fully eased my doubts about truly mastering the material.

It seems that breaking down the topics hasn't been as effective as you'd hoped in building your confidence. Let's continue exploring other strategies that might help you gain a better understanding of these challenging concepts and, ultimately, reduce your academic stress. One approach could be seeking additional resources, like online tutorials or study groups, to supplement your learning. Have you considered any of these options to support your understanding of cache memory and pipelining?

Yes, I've considered using online tutorials and joining study groups to tackle cache memory and pipelining. However, I'm still worried that these might not fully address my underlying doubts about mastering the material.

It's understandable that these additional resources might not completely eliminate your concerns. However, they could provide a fresh perspective or new explanations that may help solidify your understanding of these topics. It might be worth trying these options, as they could offer valuable support in building your confidence and reducing your academic stress. Have you considered speaking with your professor or teaching assistant about your concerns and seeking guidance on how to approach these challenging concepts?
Yes, I've considered speaking with my professor or teaching assistant about my concerns. However, I'm still unsure if that would fully alleviate my doubts about truly grasping the material.

It's natural to feel uncertain about whether seeking guidance from your professor or teaching assistant will completely resolve your concerns. However, opening a dialogue with them could provide valuable insights and clarification on complex topics like cache memory and pipelining. They may be able to offer tailored advice or resources that can help you better understand these concepts. Would you be willing to take the step of reaching out to your professor or teaching assistant to discuss your concerns and explore potential strategies for mastering the material?
I'm willing to reach out to my professor or teaching assistant as a next step, but I'm concerned it might not fully resolve my ongoing doubts about my ability to master the material.

It's important to acknowledge that addressing complex academic challenges often involves multiple steps and strategies. While reaching out to your professor or teaching assistant might not provide an immediate solution to all your concerns, it's a valuable step in the right direction. By initiating this conversation, you're taking an active role in seeking support and exploring new ways to approach these challenging topics. Remember, building confidence and reducing academic stress is a process, and each step you take contributes to your overall progress. Are there any specific questions or concerns you'd like to address when speaking with your professor or teaching assistant?

I'm concerned about discussing my gaps in understanding key concepts like cache memory and pipelining, which might be why my exam scores aren't reflecting my efforts. I'd also like to ask for strategies to build confidence in my ability to truly master the material.

When speaking with your professor or teaching assistant, it's important to be open and honest about the areas where you feel less confident, such as cache memory and pipelining. They can provide guidance and resources tailored to your specific needs, which may help bridge the gap between your efforts and exam scores. Additionally, discussing strategies for building confidence in your ability to master the material can be beneficial. Remember, they are there to support your learning journey. Would you find it helpful to prepare a list of specific questions or concerns before your meeting to ensure you cover all the essential topics?

Yes, preparing a list of specific questions would help me approach the meeting more organized and address my uncertainties effectively. It could also give me a clearer path to building the confidence I need in mastering the material.

That's a great idea. By organizing your thoughts and questions, you'll be able to make the most of your meeting and address your concerns more efficiently. To start, try writing down the key concepts you're struggling with, like cache memory and pipelining, and formulate questions that could help clarify your understanding. Additionally, consider asking for recommendations on supplemental resources or study techniques that might help you gain confidence in your ability to master the material. Would you like to share some of the questions you plan to ask during your meeting, so we can discuss any potential adjustments or additions?

Yes, I'd be open to sharing a couple of questions I've prepared, as it might help refine them to better address my uncertainties. This could assist in strengthening my confidence in grasping the material more effectively.

Great, I'm glad to hear that you're open to sharing your questions. Remember, the more specific your questions are, the more helpful your professor or teaching assistant can be in addressing your uncertainties. Feel free to share a couple of them now, and we can discuss any adjustments or additions that might further clarify your concerns. Also, keep in mind that building confidence is a process, and each step you take, like preparing these questions, contributes to your growth and understanding of the material.

I appreciate the advice on making my questions more specificI'll share one like, "How can I better understand cache memory hierarchies to improve my exam scores?" For now, I'm feeling more prepared to move forward on my own.

It sounds like you've made some progress in identifying strategies to manage your academic stress and improve your understanding of challenging topics. Remember to keep utilizing the resources available to you, such as meeting with your professor or teaching assistant and seeking additional study materials. Building confidence takes time, but each step you take brings you closer to your goals. Feel free to reach out again if you need further support or guidance. I wish you the best of luck in your academic journey, and I'm confident that with dedication and persistence, you'll be able to overcome these challenges. Take care!
Thanks for the encouragement I'll keep refining my questions and using resources to improve my understanding and aim for that A- in Computer Architecture. Take care!

concern: Completely new to college admissions. I want to be a psychiatrist and have researched the field, unfortunately my school counselor is pretty useless. Do I take pre med? What even is premed?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How's your day going so far? Is there anything specific you'd like to talk about today?
My day is going alright, though I've been feeling a bit stressed about school decisions. I'd like to discuss my future career plans and some uncertainties around my academic options.

It sounds like you've got a lot on your mind! Uncertainty about the future can definitely be stressful. Let's dive inwhat specific decisions are you facing right now regarding school and your career plans?
I'm currently deciding on my major and course selections to align with my career goals in healthcare. This uncertainty about the right academic path is what's been weighing on me lately.

It's completely understandable to feel uncertain about the best path forward when making such important decisions. It's great that you're thinking ahead about your career goals in healthcare! Have you had a chance to explore different healthcare-related majors and courses available to you?
I've done some independent research on healthcare-related majors, but I haven't explored them in depth yet. This lack of clarity is adding to my uncertainty about choosing the right path forward.

It seems like you're eager to make informed decisions about your academic path, but the vast amount of information can be overwhelming. Let's take a step back and consider this what aspects of healthcare interest you the most?
I'm most interested in mental health aspects of healthcare, as they involve helping people with their emotional well-being. This focus is key to my decisions about choosing the right academic path.

It's great to hear that you're passionate about mental health in healthcare! Mental health is an essential aspect of overall well-being and can be incredibly rewarding to study and work in. Have you considered looking into majors like psychology, counseling, or social work that directly relate to mental health?

I've considered majors like psychology as they relate to mental health, but I'm still unsure about how they align with the path to becoming a psychiatrist. This uncertainty is making it hard to decide on the right academic direction.

It's understandable to feel uncertain about how specific majors like psychology align with your goal of becoming a psychiatrist. However, it's important to remember that many mental health professionals, including psychiatrists, often start with a strong foundation in psychology. Would you like to explore the connections between psychology and psychiatry further, and how this might inform your academic choices?
Yes, I'd like to explore the connections between psychology and psychiatry further. This could help clarify my academic path toward mental health careers.

Great! Let's start by discussing how psychology provides a strong foundation for understanding human behavior, cognition, and emotions. This knowledge is essential for psychiatrists, as they work with patients to address mental health concerns. Many medical schools value applicants with diverse educational backgrounds, including those with degrees in psychology. By studying psychology, you'll gain valuable insights into mental health, which can enhance your journey toward becoming a psychiatrist.

 That makes sense. I can see how studying psychology could help me better understand mental health and prepare me for a career in psychiatry. But I'm still unsure about the specific courses I should take within psychology to best align with my goals.

 It's natural to feel unsure about specific courses within your major. Some courses that may be particularly relevant to your goals include abnormal psychology, developmental psychology, and neuroscience. Additionally, taking classes in research methods and statistics can help you develop critical thinking skills and prepare you for evidence-based practice in psychiatry. Remember, your academic advisor can be a valuable resource in guiding your course selection and ensuring you're on the right track.

 Thank you for those suggestions. I'll look into those courses and consult my academic advisor for further guidance.
That's helpful advice. I'm still figuring out if pre-med courses are necessary alongside psychology for my psychiatry goals.

It's great that you're considering various aspects of your academic path. While pre-med courses aren't always mandatory for medical school admission, they can help you build a strong foundation in the natural sciences and prepare you for the Medical College Admission Test MCAT. Many medical schools appreciate applicants with diverse backgrounds, including those who have taken pre-med courses.

That said, it's essential to balance your course load and maintain a strong GPA. You might consider taking some pre-med courses alongside your psychology courses to demonstrate your commitment to the medical field and ensure you have a well-rounded education. Keep in mind that some pre-med courses may also count towards your psychology degree requirements.

Ultimately, consulting your academic advisor will help you make informed decisions about course selection and create an individualized plan that aligns with your goals.

I appreciate the advice on pre-med courses and their role in preparing for medical school. I'm still trying to figure out how to balance them with my psychology studies without affecting my overall performance.

It's understandable that balancing coursework can be challenging. Here are some tips to help you manage your studies effectively

1. Create a schedule Plan your study time and stick to it. Allocate specific hours for each subject and ensure you cover all necessary material.
2. Utilize resources Make use of campus resources such as tutoring centers, study groups, and academic advising to support your learning.
3. Develop effective study habits Find study methods that work best for you, such as active note-taking, flashcards, or teaching concepts to others.
4. Prioritize self-care Ensure you get enough sleep, exercise, and maintain a healthy diet to support your mental and physical well-being.

Remember, it's essential to stay organized, seek help when needed, and prioritize your well-being throughout your academic journey. With careful planning and dedication, you can successfully balance your coursework and excel in both psychology and pre-med courses.
Thanks for the study tips I'll focus on balancing my pre-med and psychology courses to stay on track for my psychiatry goals without overwhelming myself.

It's great to see your dedication and willingness to find a balance in your academic pursuits. Remember that it's important to stay organized and seek help when needed. With careful planning and commitment, you can successfully navigate your coursework and achieve your goals. Keep up the good work, and don't hesitate to reach out for support along the way. Best of luck on your journey towards becoming a psychiatrist!
Thanks for the encouragement I'll keep prioritizing that balance between my pre-med courses and psychology to stay on track for psychiatry. Take care!

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Whats on your mind today? Im all ears well, metaphorically speaking, anyway .
I'm feeling pretty anxious about my recent changes in college. It's been weighing on me as I try to move forward.

Change can be tough to navigate, and its totally understandable that it might be causing some anxiety. Do you feel comfortable sharing more about the specific changes that are causing these feelings?
 Sure, I just transferred to a new college, and I'm struggling to make friends. It's like everyone already has their groups and I'm the odd one out.

I appreciate you listening it's not just about making friends, but also feeling uncertain about how my previous coursework aligns with my new direction. This uncertainty is making it harder for me to feel settled in my studies.

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of change all at once. Not only are you navigating a new social environment, but you're also questioning the academic path you've chosen. It's completely normal to feel unsettled and anxious in these situations. Have you considered reaching out to any academic advisors or counselors on campus for guidance and support?

I have already reached out to academic advisors and therapists on campus to discuss my academic uncertainties. It's been helpful in starting to process how these changes are affecting my overall progress.

It's great that you've taken the initiative to seek support from advisors and therapists on campus. Building a strong support network can be really beneficial as you navigate these challenges. How has talking to them helped you process your feelings about the changes you're experiencing?

Talking to the advisors and therapists has helped me gain some clarity on my emotions, making the transitions feel less overwhelming. It's allowed me to start reframing my uncertainties into more manageable steps forward.

It's wonderful to hear that seeking support has helped you gain clarity and break down your uncertainties into manageable steps. Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and be kind to yourself throughout this process. Do you think there are any other resources or activities on campus that might help you continue building your support network and finding your place in this new environment?

I think joining campus clubs related to my new major could help me build connections and gain practical insights. Additionally, attending academic workshops might provide more strategies to manage the transitions in my studies.

That's an excellent idea! Joining clubs and attending workshops are fantastic ways to not only expand your knowledge but also create meaningful connections with like-minded individuals who may be experiencing similar challenges. Engaging in these activities can help you feel more connected to your new college community and provide you with a stronger sense of belonging. Which clubs or workshops are you most interested in exploring?

I'm most interested in clubs related to environmental science, as they could help me connect with peers in my new field. Additionally, workshops on career planning might assist in making the most of my academic path moving forward.

It sounds like you have a clear plan in mind! Engaging in environmental science clubs and career planning workshops will provide valuable opportunities to build connections and develop strategies for your academic journey. When considering these options, it might be helpful to set specific goals and timelines for joining clubs or attending workshops. This can help you stay on track and maintain a sense of progress. Would you like to discuss how you might get started with these activities?
Yes, I'd like to discuss how to get started with these activities to help me navigate my academic adjustments. This could make the process feel more manageable as I move forward.

Starting with small, achievable steps can indeed make the process more manageable. One way to begin is by reaching out to the student organizations department or visiting your college's website to explore available clubs related to environmental science. You could also connect with your academic advisor or professors to inquire about upcoming career planning workshops or similar events. Would you prefer to start with contacting the student organizations department or consulting with your academic advisor?

I'd prefer to start by contacting the student organizations department to explore environmental science clubs. This approach will help me build a supportive network as I adapt to my new academic direction.

Great, it's wonderful to see that you have a clear starting point! Contacting the student organizations department to explore environmental science clubs is a fantastic first step in building connections and finding support during your academic journey. Remember to be patient with yourself throughout this process, as it may take time to find the right clubs and develop meaningful relationships. Stay focused on your goals, and don't hesitate to reach out for additional support if needed. Keep up the positive momentum, and best of luck in your new academic path! Please feel free to follow up with me in a month to discuss your progress and any further support you may need.
Thanks for the guidanceI'll reach out to the student organizations department soon to build that support network, and I'll check back with you in a month as things progress.

i’m transferring to a university and want to be as prepared as possible !!

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Whats on your mind today?
I'm feeling anxious about my upcoming transfer to university and how to get ready for it. I want to make sure I'm as prepared as possible for this new chapter.

That's totally understandable. Moving to a new school can be both exciting and nerve-wracking. What specifically are you feeling anxious about?
 I think I'm mostly worried about being able to keep up with the coursework, making new friends, and adjusting to living on my own for the first time.
I'm mainly anxious about managing the academic demands and building a new social circle. I want to feel more confident in preparing for this big transition.

It sounds like you're facing some big changes, but also some exciting opportunities for growth. Let's start with the academic piece - what are some things you've done in the past that have helped you feel more confident in your academic abilities?

In the past, I've relied on creating detailed study schedules and seeking help from tutors when needed, which helped me manage coursework effectively. These strategies made me feel more in control and ready for academic challenges.

Those are excellent strategies! It's great that you've identified methods that have worked for you in the past. Building on that, how might you adapt those strategies to your new university environment to help you manage your coursework and feel more prepared?

I could adapt my study schedules by incorporating the university's academic calendar and online resources to better fit the new pace, making it easier to stay organized. Additionally, I'd seek out campus tutoring centers or study groups early on to build familiarity and boost my confidence in handling the coursework.

That's a fantastic plan! To ensure you follow through with these strategies, would it be helpful to set specific goals for yourself, such as attending at least one tutoring session or study group per week, or reviewing your study schedule daily? Which of these goals feels more achievable for you?

Remember to keep your response within the Phase 3 Choosing guidelines, focusing on concrete action plans, addressing potential barriers, and maintaining a concise, autonomy-supportive tone.

Yes, setting specific goals like attending a tutoring session or study group once a week would help me stay accountable and prepared. Reviewing my study schedule daily feels more achievable as it's a quick habit I can easily integrate into my routine to maintain control over my coursework.

It's great to see that you've identified specific strategies and goals to help you manage your coursework and feel more confident in your transition to university. Remember to stay consistent with your daily study schedule reviews and weekly tutoring sessions or study group attendance. By staying committed to these goals, you'll be better equipped to handle the academic demands and build connections with your peers. Feel free to reach out for additional support if needed. Best of luck with your transition, and remember that you've got this!
Thanks for the encouragement I'll commit to my weekly study group and daily schedule reviews to stay on track and feel more prepared for university life.
