concern: Looking to work 3 or 4 days 10 hours but not sure how many classes to take.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and provide support as you share your thoughts and concerns. What's been on your mind lately?
I've been feeling unsure about balancing my work and school schedule lately. It's been on my mind as I try to figure out a manageable routine.
Balancing work and school can be a tough juggling act. It sounds like you're really trying to find a way to make it all work. What specific concerns have come up for you in this process?
I've been worried about how to align my work hours with my class load without overwhelming myself. It's challenging to decide on the right number of classes while keeping up with my job commitments.

That's a valid concern. It's important to find that sweet spot where you can manage both your work and school responsibilities without burning out. Have you considered creating a schedule or time-blocking to help visualize how everything might fit together?

I've thought about trying to create a schedule, but I'm not sure how to make it work with my commitments. It might help me figure out if I can handle my classes alongside my work without feeling overwhelmed.

It's great that you're open to trying out a schedule. One way to start could be by making a list of your classes and work hours, then seeing how they fit into a weekly calendar. That way, you can get a clearer picture of your commitments and identify any potential conflicts or areas of concern. Do you think this would be a helpful first step?

Yes, I think creating a schedule like that could be a helpful first step to get a better handle on my commitments. It might help me avoid feeling overwhelmed by visually seeing how my work and classes could align.

Great, creating a schedule can be a powerful tool to help you balance your responsibilities and feel more in control. As you start building your schedule, remember to also consider setting aside some time for self-care and relaxation. This can help prevent burnout and keep you feeling your best. Do you have any ideas for how you might incorporate self-care into your routine?
I could try incorporating short daily walks or meditation sessions into my evenings to help me unwind. This might allow me to recharge and maintain balance with my other commitments.

That's a wonderful idea! Taking time for self-care activities like walks or meditation can be incredibly beneficial for your overall well-being and help you stay balanced. As you create your schedule, try to be consistent with your self-care time, making it a priority just like your work and classes. This will help ensure you're taking care of yourself and feeling more in control of your routine. Would you like to start building your schedule today and see how it feels?
Yes, I'd like to start building my schedule today to see how it fits. This could help me better manage my time and avoid feeling overwhelmed.

Excellent! Starting today will give you a head start in managing your time effectively. To make the process more manageable, you might consider breaking down your schedule into smaller tasks, such as adding classes first, then work hours, and finally self-care activities. This can help you focus on one aspect at a time and make adjustments as needed. Which part of your schedule would you like to tackle first?
I'd like to tackle the classes first. This will help me organize my time around them effectively.

Great! Starting with your classes is an excellent way to build your schedule. Once you've organized your classes, we can move on to incorporating your work hours and self-care activities. Remember, it's essential to maintain a balance between your responsibilities and personal well-being. After you've made some progress with your schedule, feel free to reach out and let me know how it's going. I'm here to support you in creating a routine that works best for you. Good luck, and remember to take it one step at a time!
Thank you for the guidance I'll start with my classes and make sure to fit in my 3 or 4 work days without overloading myself. I'll reach out if I need more help.

It's been a pleasure working with you on creating a balanced schedule. Remember to take it one step at a time, and feel free to reach out for additional support whenever needed. I'm here to help you maintain a healthy balance between your work, school, and self-care activities. Good luck, and I look forward to hearing about your progress!
Thanks for your support I'll focus on balancing my classes with those 3 or 4 work days to avoid burnout. Take care!

It's great to see your commitment to finding a balance between your work and school responsibilities. Remember to be patient with yourself and make adjustments as needed. Keep up the good work, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance. Take care, and best of luck in maintaining your balanced routine!
I appreciate your encouragementI'll keep focusing on balancing my classes with those 3 or 4 work days to stay on track. Thanks and take care!

Keep up the good work, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance. Take care, and best of luck in maintaining your balanced routine!
client: I appreciate your encouragementI'll keep focusing on balancing my classes with those 3 or 4 work days to stay on track. Thanks and take care!

concern:
Okay so I commute a half hour (45-60 mins to the college campus at most)

I have made some connections, but I don’t know if they are good enough. 

I like and hate the idea of having a dorm and room. Not because I am a shy introvert, but I just don’t really know to feel about the idea of living on a college campus. Several reasons for that. 

Overall:
I like the privacy.
I like my home. 
I like living with my family and dog.
I don’t want to spend more money. 
I think I probably focus better at home. 
I’m kind of uncomfortable living elsewhere especially on that campus. 

I’m considering possibly moving to an apartment for my second year or a later year in college or near it but I don’t know if I want to just yet. I am in state so I have a home and live with my family which is nice and I like it, but the commute can be tiring and long also it is harder to attend late night club events. But the college campus area isn’t the best and safest place (suburban/urban college city/town) although it is a large 4 year university the location is in an area I don’t really like. 

I would say the exact college, but I don’t think I can do that here.

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there, how's your day going so far?
My day has been okay, but the commute is starting to feel exhausting. I'm trying to stay focused on my routines despite some ongoing uncertainties.
It sounds like you're working hard to keep your routines in place, even with some things up in the air. That can be tough, especially when you're dealing with a tiring commute.
Yeah, the commute is definitely wearing me down, making it harder to balance everything. I'm still weighing my options at home versus campus to see what might help me feel more settled.

It seems like finding the right balance between your home and campus life could help alleviate some of the stress you're experiencing from your commute. Have you considered any specific changes that might make things easier?
I've thought about possibly renting an apartment closer to campus for later years to cut down on the commute. For now, I'm trying to adjust my schedule at home to make daily routines more manageable.

It's great that you're actively thinking about solutions to improve your situation. It can be helpful to consider both short-term adjustments and long-term changes to find the right balance for you. Remember to take care of yourself during this process and be patient as you navigate these challenges.
I'm appreciating the reminder to be patient with myself during this adjustment. For now, I'm focusing on small changes like tweaking my daily routine to ease the commute's impact.

Making small changes to your daily routine can be a great way to manage the stress caused by your commute. Remember that even small steps can lead to significant improvements in your overall well-being. Are there any specific adjustments you're planning to make in the coming days?
I'm planning to adjust my wake-up time and organize my evening routine to better prepare for the commute. This should help me maintain my focus and comfort at home while easing daily stresses.

It's encouraging to see that you're taking steps to adapt your routine and make your daily life more manageable. Making small adjustments, like changing your wake-up time and organizing your evening routine, can have a positive impact on your overall well-being. Remember to give yourself time to adjust to these changes and monitor how they affect your energy levels and mood.
I'll keep an eye on how these routine changes influence my energy and mood each day. This approach might help me balance my home comfort with the demands of commuting.

That's a great approach. Keeping track of your energy levels and mood will help you determine if these changes are effective. You might also consider experimenting with different relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, to help ease any remaining stress from your commute.
I'll consider trying deep breathing or meditation during my commute to see if it reduces my stress. This could help me maintain my focus and comfort while balancing home life with college demands.

It's great that you're open to trying relaxation techniques like deep breathing and meditation during your commute. These practices can be very helpful in managing stress and maintaining focus. As we wrap up our conversation today, remember to be patient with yourself as you implement these changes and keep track of their impact on your energy levels and mood. We can revisit your progress and discuss any further adjustments during our next session. Take care, and I look forward to speaking with you again soon.
Thanks for the suggestions I'll try those relaxation techniques to manage my commute stress while prioritizing my comfort and focus at home. Take care and see you next time.

concern:
I'm in Scotland so I don't have to worry about the financial side or the bus fare (for the ones who aren't aware, in Scotland you get free education, not sure if it's up to a certain age? And I get a free bus pass because I'm under 23) 

I've always been interested in psychology, criminology history etc and at the college I'm currently attending they have a year course that basically covers it all (including a few more things like geography, social anthropology, environment science and a few others).

I'm going into animal care (currently the plan is zoo-keeping, however we will see where that takes me :)) so that other course will have no benefit to my future as I will not need it at all but should I take it for  the information? 

Definitely a stupid question but just curious what others think

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! What's been on your mind lately? I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and feelings.

I've been weighing my options about taking extra courses that interest me, even if they're not directly related to my planned career in animal care. It's got me thinking about how to balance personal curiosity with practical decisions.

It sounds like you're in a bit of a dilemma, wanting to pursue your interests while also being mindful of your future career goals. It's great that you're thinking about both aspects! Let's explore this furtherwhat kind of courses are you considering taking?

I'm considering courses in psychology, criminology, and history, which fascinate me personally. Even though they're not directly linked to my animal care career path, I'm wondering if pursuing them for knowledge alone is worthwhile.

It's wonderful that you're interested in a variety of subjects! Pursuing knowledge for its own sake can be incredibly rewarding and enriching. Plus, you never know how these seemingly unrelated courses might come in handy down the line. Have you thought about how taking these courses might impact your time and resources, and whether you're comfortable with that trade-off?

I've thought about how taking those courses might take up more of my time, but since education is free here, it won't strain my resources much. I'm okay with the trade-off if it means satisfying my curiosity without derailing my animal care goals.

It's great that you're comfortable with the trade-off and are willing to invest your time in pursuing these interests! Exploring diverse subjects can broaden your perspective and potentially enhance your skills in various areas. It's important to remember that learning doesn't always have to be directly linked to a career goalsometimes, it can simply be for personal growth and satisfaction. What do you think would be the best way to balance your time between these extra courses and your animal care studies?

I think the best way to balance my time is by prioritizing my animal care studies while scheduling the extra courses during lighter periods or breaks. That way, I can still pursue my personal interests without overwhelming my main career path.

That sounds like a great plan! By prioritizing your animal care studies and strategically scheduling the additional courses, you can maintain a balance between your career goals and personal interests. Plus, exploring these subjects during breaks or lighter periods can provide a refreshing change of pace and help prevent burnout. Do you feel confident in your ability to stick to this plan and effectively manage your time?

Yes, I feel confident in my ability to stick to this plan, as I've successfully managed similar schedules before. By keeping my animal care studies as the priority, I can explore other interests without letting them overshadow my main goals.

It's wonderful to see that you have a clear plan in place to balance your animal care studies with your additional courses in psychology, criminology, and history. By prioritizing your career goals while still making time for personal interests, you can enrich your learning experience and maintain a sense of fulfillment. Remember to be mindful of your time management and stay flexible as you navigate through your studies. I'm confident that you'll be able to successfully handle this plan, especially given your past experiences. Good luck with your studies, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need any further support!
Thank you for your support I'll prioritize my animal care studies while exploring my interests in psychology and criminology during breaks, and I'll reach out if I need more help.

concern:
After basically getting through college and high school running on what I presume was the last of my motivation, I \[F26\] got my bachelors in biology, and after a couple jobs have landed in a place where I'm happy, but need to get a raise. Going back to school for a masters never really was an option for me and isn't really something I'd like to pursue, but I decided to try taking some certificate CC classes in an effort to boost my skills to either get a raise or a better job.

Hence... now I'm 2 weeks into class, and I just... can't. I never was able to focus well, and basically got through college by hyperfixating on my studies and \*school was my life\* but that doesn't work when you're a grown up and have outside obligations like a full time job and being a healthy human for the first time in my life. I tried putting in what I assumed was the amount of effort that normal people put into school (I did the readings, the lectures, the assignment), and still failed my first assignment and I feel so discouraged at the moment.

How do I focus and figure out how to "absorb" information in ways other than letting school consume my life... I'm seriously super close to just dropping out and never looking back at school but it feels like it might be my only option to eventually get the salary I want.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! What's on your mind today? I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and feelings.
I'm struggling to focus on my classes while balancing my full-time job and other responsibilities. I'm feeling discouraged about my progress and want to find better ways to manage this.
That sounds like a lot on your plate. Its understandable that you might feel discouraged. Whats been the biggest challenge in managing everything?

The biggest challenge has been maintaining focus on my studies while juggling my full-time job and other daily responsibilities. It feels overwhelming to absorb the material without letting it take over my entire life like before.

It's tough to strike that balance. It's clear you want to make progress without sacrificing your well-being. Have you tried breaking your studies into smaller, more manageable chunks of time, or setting aside specific times for work and study?

I've tried setting aside specific times for studying, but it hasn't helped much with maintaining focus amid my other responsibilities. Breaking things into smaller chunks sounds promising, though I'm not sure if I can make it stick without it feeling overwhelming.
It's great that you're open to trying new strategies. What do you think would make it more likely for you to stick to a more manageable study schedule without feeling overwhelmed?

I think having an accountability partner or using simple apps for reminders could help me stay consistent without adding more pressure. Incorporating quick rewards after study sessions might also make it feel less overwhelming while keeping my overall life balanced.

Having an accountability partner and using reminder apps sound like practical strategies to stay consistent without adding pressure. Which friend or app would you like to start with as your accountability partner and reminder system?

I think my coworker Sarah, who's also taking classes, could be a good accountability partner to start with. For the reminder system, I'd like to try the Habitica app to keep things simple and gamified without overwhelming my routine.

In summary, you've identified key strategies to manage your studies better, including breaking them into smaller chunks, having an accountability partner in Sarah, and using the Habitica app for reminders. Remember to reward yourself for progress and maintain a balanced life. Let's check in next week to see how these strategies are working for you.
I'm looking forward to trying these strategies with Sarah and the app to keep my studies manageable without letting them take over my life. See you next week for an update.

concern: I’m a third year Construction Management student and I want to start to work in that industry. Idk where to start. I tried looking and applying for General Laborer positions in construction but none has accept me and some reject my applications. I went to a few internship interviews, but no call backs at all post interviews. Idk what else to do

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! I'm here to listen. What's been on your mind lately?
I've been feeling unsure about how to break into the construction industry as a student. It's frustrating not knowing the next steps to get started.

That sounds like a challenging situation. Navigating the job market can be tough, especially when you're just starting out. It's understandable that you're feeling unsure. Have you looked into any resources or support available for students interested in construction?
Yes, I've tried applying for entry-level positions and internships in construction. I'm starting to look into university resources for more guidance on getting started.

It's great that you're taking proactive steps and exploring resources. Reaching out to university resources can be a great way to get advice and learn about opportunities in the field. Have you considered networking with professionals in the construction industry? Sometimes making connections can lead to valuable insights and opportunities.
I've considered networking with professionals in the construction industry, but I haven't figured out the best way to get started. It's been tough navigating these initial steps on my own.

It seems like you're taking some positive steps towards your goal of entering the construction industry, but you're still struggling with the initial steps. Networking can be challenging, especially when you're not sure where to start. Have you thought about attending any industry events or career fairs where you could connect with professionals in the field?
Yes, I've thought about attending industry events and career fairs to connect with professionals. It's challenging for me to figure out the next steps in making those connections happen.

It's understandable that navigating these initial steps can feel overwhelming. One approach could be to research upcoming events and career fairs in your area or online, and then make a plan to attend. This can be a great way to learn more about the industry and connect with professionals who can offer guidance and support.

I've been trying to research events and fairs as you suggested, but it's still tough to turn those into actual connections. I'm worried that without more direction, I might not make the progress I need in my job search.

It sounds like you're still feeling unsure about how to translate event attendance into meaningful connections. It might be helpful to set specific goals for each event, such as introducing yourself to a certain number of professionals or asking for advice from people in roles you're interested in. This can give you a clear focus and help you make the most of these opportunities.

I've thought about setting goals for events, like aiming to talk to a few professionals, but I'm still unsure how to make those interactions lead to real opportunities. It's frustrating because I feel like I'm not gaining the momentum I need in my career path.

It's natural to feel uncertain about how to turn event interactions into tangible opportunities. One strategy could be to follow up with the professionals you meet after the event, perhaps via email or LinkedIn. Express gratitude for their time and insights, reiterate your interest in their field, and ask if they have any additional advice or resources to share. This can help maintain the connection and potentially open doors for future opportunities.

I'll give following up a try, like sending thank-you emails, but I'm still anxious that it won't translate into actual job leads in construction. How can I make sure I'm approaching this in the most effective way?

Your concerns are understandable, and it's good that you're considering various strategies. One way to increase your chances of success is to tailor your follow-up messages to each professional you met, referencing specific topics you discussed or common interests you discovered during the event. This personal touch can make you more memorable and increase the likelihood of a response. Additionally, consider asking for informational interviews or job shadowing opportunities, as these can provide valuable insights into the industry and potentially lead to job offers.

I appreciate the suggestion on tailoring follow-ups it makes sense to make them more personal to stand out in the competitive construction field. Still, I'm worried that even with these efforts, I might not see the job leads I need, so how can I track my progress to stay motivated?

Tracking progress is important for staying motivated, especially in a competitive field like construction. One way to do this is by setting specific, measurable goals for each networking event you attend. For example, aim to connect with at least three professionals in your area of interest or secure two informational interviews per month. By quantifying your efforts, you can better assess your progress and identify areas for improvement. Additionally, celebrate small victories along the way, such as receiving a response from a professional or gaining new insights about the industry. Recognizing these achievements can help maintain your momentum and enthusiasm throughout the job search process.

I'll try setting specific goals like you suggested to measure my networking efforts, as that could help me stay motivated in this tough job hunt. Even with tracking, I'm still anxious that it might not turn into the construction opportunities I need.

It's great that you're open to setting specific goals. To further support your job search, consider utilizing online platforms and job boards specifically tailored to the construction industry. Websites like ConstructionJobs.com, CareerBuilder, and Indeed often list entry-level positions and internships that can help you gain valuable experience. Additionally, joining professional associations or trade organizations, such as the Associated General Contractors of America AGC, can provide access to job listings, industry events, and networking opportunities.

 I haven't explored industry-specific job boards yet, but it sounds like a promising avenue to find relevant opportunities. I'll also look into joining professional associations like AGC. However, I'm still concerned about balancing my academic commitments with the time required for networking and job searching.

 Balancing academic commitments with job search activities can be challenging, but it's important to prioritize and manage your time effectively. Consider dedicating specific blocks of time each week for job search activities, such as researching companies, attending events, or sending follow-up messages. This can help you stay organized and make progress without overwhelming your schedule.

I'll try dedicating specific time blocks for job searching as you suggested to keep things organized, but I'm worried that even with better time management, it won't translate into the construction opportunities I'm aiming for. How can I ensure I'm not burning out while juggling all this?

It's important to prioritize self-care and maintain a healthy work-life balance during your job search. Here are a few tips to prevent burnout

1. Take regular breaks Schedule time for relaxation, exercise, or hobbies to help you recharge.
2. Seek support Connect with friends, family, or mentors who can provide encouragement and advice during this process.
3. Practice mindfulness Techniques like meditation or journaling can help manage stress and maintain perspective.

Remember, your well-being is essential for long-term success. Prioritize self-care and be patient with the process. With dedication and persistence, you'll increase your chances of finding the right opportunities in the construction industry.

I'll definitely try incorporating breaks and mindfulness into my routine to prevent burnout, but I'm still worried that all this effort might not lead to the construction opportunities I need. Thanks for your help today.

I understand your concerns, but remember that persistence and dedication are key in any job search. Keep implementing the strategies we discussed, such as networking, utilizing industry-specific job boards, and setting measurable goals. Stay connected with your support system, and don't hesitate to reach out for further guidance or assistance. I'm here to support you on your journey. Feel free to follow up with me in a few weeks to discuss your progress and address any new concerns. Take care, and best of luck in your job search!

I'll keep working on those strategies and staying connected for support, but I'm still anxious that my efforts won't lead to the construction opportunities I need. Thanks for your helpI'll reach out if things don't improve.

Additionally, joining professional associations or trade organizations, such as the Associated General Contractors of America AGC, can provide access to job listings, industry events, and networking opportunities.

 I haven't explored industry-specific job boards yet, but it sounds like a promising avenue to find relevant opportunities. I'll also look into joining professional associations like AGC. However, I'm still concerned about balancing my academic commitments with the time required for networking and job searching.

 Balancing academic commitments with job search activities can be challenging, but it's important to prioritize and manage your time effectively. Consider dedicating specific blocks of time each week for job search activities, such as researching companies, attending events, or sending follow-up messages. This can help you stay organized and make progress without overwhelming your schedule.
client: I'll try dedicating specific time blocks for job searching as you suggested to keep things organized, but I'm worried that even with better time management, it won't translate into the construction opportunities I'm aiming for. How can I ensure I'm not burning out while juggling all this?
therapist: It's important to prioritize self-care and maintain a healthy work-life balance during your job search. Here are a few tips to prevent burnout

1. Take regular breaks Schedule time for relaxation, exercise, or hobbies to help you recharge.
2. Seek support Connect with friends, family, or mentors who can provide encouragement and advice during this process.
3. Practice mindfulness Techniques like meditation or journaling can help manage stress and maintain perspective.

Remember, your well-being is essential for long-term success. Prioritize self-care and be patient with the process. With dedication and persistence, you'll increase your chances of finding the right opportunities in the construction industry.
client: I'll definitely try incorporating breaks and mindfulness into my routine to prevent burnout, but I'm still worried that all this effort might not lead to the construction opportunities I need. Thanks for your help today.
therapist: I understand your concerns, but remember that persistence and dedication are key in any job search. Keep implementing the strategies we discussed, such as networking, utilizing industry-specific job boards, and setting measurable goals. Stay connected with your support system, and don't hesitate to reach out for further guidance or assistance. I'm here to support you on your journey. Feel free to follow up with me in a few weeks to discuss your progress and address any new concerns. Take care, and best of luck in your job search!
client: I'll keep working on those strategies and staying connected for support, but I'm still anxious that my efforts won't lead to the construction opportunities I need. Thanks for your helpI'll reach out if things don't improve.

concern: Hello there, I was in the military for 4 years after graduating high school. I got out, got married, went straight to work. I want to go get a bachelors in Computer Science, and I have applied to my local community college and will start in the fall of this year. Ive not registered for classes yet. I do see that I will take Calculus 1. I am very scared of taking this. How exactly do I prepare for this? I dont remember much of math from high school. Thank you

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome, and thank you for being here. Whats on your mind today?
I'm feeling anxious about starting my college courses, particularly the math involved. I want to figure out how to rebuild my skills since it's been a while since high school.

It's totally understandable to feel anxious about college courses, especially if it's been a while since you've tackled math. Building up your skills again can seem daunting, but it's great that you're thinking ahead and wanting to be prepared. What specific areas of math are you worried about?
I'm particularly worried about calculus and its foundational concepts. It's been a while since I've engaged with math, so I'm eager to rebuild those skills.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit out of practice with math, especially calculus. That's a common experience for folks returning to school after some time away. It's really admirable that you're wanting to rebuild those skills and tackle the challenge head-on. What kind of resources do you have available to help you get back into the swing of things?
I have access to online resources like Khan Academy and the college's tutoring center to help me review math concepts. I'm hoping these will build my confidence as I prepare for calculus.

It's great that you're taking advantage of resources like Khan Academy and your college's tutoring center to review math concepts and build your confidence. These can be really helpful tools as you work to rebuild your skills and prepare for calculus. As you begin this process, remember to be patient with yourself and give yourself the time you need to re-familiarize yourself with the material. It's completely normal to feel a bit overwhelmed at first, but with consistent effort and the right support, you'll likely find that you can make significant progress. Is there anything else you're considering doing to help you get ready for your college courses?

I'm also thinking about reviewing algebra and pre-calculus basics on my own using workbooks before classes start. Additionally, I might reach out to a math advisor at the college for personalized guidance to ease back into the material.

It's fantastic that you're taking a proactive approach by considering workbooks and seeking personalized guidance from a math advisor. These strategies can really help you feel more prepared and confident as you tackle your college courses. Remember to take things one step at a time and celebrate your progress along the way. Are there any specific concerns or areas of math that you're feeling particularly anxious about?

I'm particularly anxious about algebra and basic functions since they were rusty from high school and are essential for calculus. This uncertainty makes me worry about keeping up in class despite my preparation efforts.

It's understandable to feel anxious about algebra and basic functions, especially since they serve as building blocks for calculus. However, recognizing these areas of concern is an important first step in addressing them. As you continue to review and practice these concepts, try to focus on the progress you're making rather than dwelling on any initial struggles. Building a strong foundation in these areas will not only help you succeed in calculus but also boost your overall confidence in math. Do you think it might be helpful to create a study schedule or set specific goals for your preparation efforts?

Yes, I think creating a study schedule and setting specific goals would be helpful for keeping me organized and on track with my math preparation. It could help ease my anxiety by breaking down the material into manageable steps as I work towards feeling more confident in calculus.

That's great! Breaking down the material into manageable steps can indeed make the process less overwhelming and help you stay focused. As you create your study schedule, consider allocating specific time slots for reviewing algebra and basic functions. This will ensure that you dedicate enough time to reinforce these essential concepts. Additionally, setting smaller, achievable goals will allow you to monitor your progress and celebrate your accomplishments along the way. Would you like to share some of the goals you have in mind?

Yes, I'd be happy to share a couple of goals. My main ones are to review algebra basics like solving equations and graphing functions over the next few weeks, and to practice calculus problems daily to build my confidence and reduce my anxiety about the course.

Those are excellent goals! By dedicating time to reviewing algebra basics and practicing calculus problems regularly, you'll be taking important steps towards building a strong foundation and increasing your confidence. Remember to be patient with yourself during this process and celebrate your progress along the way. As you work through these goals, consider using various resources such as online tutorials, practice problems, and your college's tutoring center to support your learning. Additionally, you might find it helpful to create a progress chart or journal to track your achievements and reflect on any challenges you encounter. This can help you stay motivated and make any necessary adjustments to your study plan. Do you think these strategies would be beneficial for you?

Yes, I think these strategies would be beneficial because they could help me build a structured approach to studying and reduce my overall anxiety about math. Incorporating them into my plan feels like a practical way to stay motivated and track my progress.

I'm glad you find these strategies helpful. As you move forward with your study plan, it's essential to be kind to yourself and remember that it's okay to make mistakes or encounter challenges along the way. Embrace these moments as opportunities for growth and learning. Additionally, it might be helpful to establish a support system by connecting with fellow students, joining study groups, or reaching out to your math advisor when needed. Building a network of peers who share similar goals can provide encouragement and foster a sense of community. Do you think you might benefit from seeking out such support?
Yes, I think seeking out support from peers or advisors could be beneficial for me. It might help me feel more confident and less overwhelmed as I work towards my goals.

It's great to see that you're open to seeking support from your peers and advisors. Remember, creating a strong support system can make a significant difference in your academic journey. As you implement your study plan, continue to reflect on your progress, celebrate your achievements, and make adjustments as needed. With dedication and perseverance, you'll be well on your way to rebuilding your math skills and tackling your college courses with confidence. I wish you the best of luck, and remember that you have the resources and support to succeed. Feel free to reach out again if you have any further concerns or need additional guidance. Take care!
Thank you for your guidance I'll reach out to peers and advisors as I work on my math preparation to feel more confident going into Calculus. Take care!

concern:
I had this fantastical delusion of grandeur regarding that the professors would be the very best part of going to college. Unfortunately, I am acutely aware of how much they truly hate us, at least most of them! Maybe it's better for grad students? Then, I made a gargantuan mistake by joining their Reddit group r/Professors. The same can be said for the r/AskProfessors . It's so very depressing! I keep praying that my professors are different 

They spew the meanest things about their students on these communities. In r/Professors we can't even respond or post, and on r/AskProfessors students can't post without content review. So, let's have our own COLLEGE STUDENTS ONLY community where we forbid comments/posts when we share the REAL order of things. Thoughts?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! What's on your mind today? I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and feelings.
I'm feeling really disappointed because my high expectations about professors in college aren't matching up with reality. I'm hoping to explore ways to manage these feelings and shift my perspective.

That sounds really tough, especially when you've been looking forward to this experience. It's natural to feel disappointed when things don't meet our expectations. Let's talk through what's been happening and see if we can find some ways to help you cope with these feelings and maybe reframe your perspective a bit. What specifically has been different than what you expected?
I've found that professors are coming across as more distant and unsupportive than I expected them to be. This has left me feeling more disillusioned and unsure about my college experience.

It's definitely tough to feel like the people who are supposed to be supporting and guiding you are distant and unsupportive. That can be really disheartening, especially when you're in a new environment like college. It's understandable that you're feeling disillusioned. Have you had any positive interactions with professors, or is it a consistent pattern across the board?

I've mostly experienced professors as distant and unsupportive, with very few positive interactions so far. This pattern has made it hard to shake off my initial disappointment in how things are turning out.

It's completely valid to feel disappointed and frustrated when your expectations aren't met, especially in a new environment like college. It's important to acknowledge those feelings, but also consider how you might adapt and make the most of your experience despite these challenges. Have you thought about any ways you could potentially approach your professors or seek additional support from other sources on campus?

I've thought about approaching my professors, but I'm hesitant given how distant they've felt so far. I've also considered seeking support from other campus resources, like student advisors or peer groups, to help navigate this.

It's great that you're considering seeking support from other resources on campus. Student advisors and peer groups can offer valuable guidance and perspectives that may help you navigate these challenges. They might also provide insights into how to approach your professors effectively or suggest alternative ways to build connections with them. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are people and resources available to help you make the most of your college experience. Would you like to explore these options further and discuss how you might take those initial steps?

I'm open to discussing how to take those initial steps with campus resources, as I'm hoping it might help me feel less isolated. Still, I'm hesitant about engaging with professors given my experiences so far.

It's understandable to feel hesitant about engaging with professors, but remember that seeking support from other resources like student advisors or peer groups can help you navigate those interactions more effectively. It's important to take things at your own pace, so let's focus on exploring the initial steps you can take with campus resources. What do you think would be the best way for you to start seeking support from student advisors or peer groups?

I think starting with an appointment at the student advising center would be a good first step, as it feels less intimidating than approaching professors directly. Once I connect with peers in a group, I hope it could help me build confidence in handling those interactions without feeling so isolated.

That sounds like a great plan! Making an appointment at the student advising center is a proactive step toward finding the support you need. It's important to remember that they are there to help you navigate challenges and connect with resources that can improve your college experience. When do you think you'll schedule that appointment, and would you like any help preparing for it?

I'll probably schedule the appointment at the student advising center next week, as I want to ease into this without rushing. I could use some general tips on how to prepare, to help me feel more confident in seeking support amidst my uncertainties.

Great! Here are a few tips to help you prepare for your appointment at the student advising center

1. Write down your concerns and specific questions beforehand, so you don't forget anything important.
2. Reflect on your goals and what you hope to achieve by seeking support, as this will help guide the conversation.
3. Remember that the advisors are there to help you, so be open and honest about your experiences and feelings.

I'm glad you're taking this step to seek support, and I wish you all the best in your appointment. Remember, you can always reach out again if you need more assistance or guidance.
Thanks for the tips they'll help me feel more prepared to share my concerns about professors and find the support I need. I'll let you know how the appointment goes.

concern:
So….I got a bachelors degree with a good GPA. After college I attended a community college to pursue an additional associates and ended up getting an F and a W on my transcript (for a long winded reason) and didn’t go back. 

I want to get my masters online and was wondering, is it possible for the admissions to be unaware of my one community college semester if I don’t submit the transcript ? I didn’t receive financial aid and paid out of pocket. And if they would know I went there without me disclosing it, how would they find that out?

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! Whats been on your mind lately? Is there something youd like to talk about? Im all ears and ready to listen.
I've been feeling anxious about my academic past and how it might impact my future goals. I'd like to talk about ways to handle this stress and move forward positively.

It sounds like you've got some worries about how your past academic experiences might affect your future plans. That's a totally valid concern, and it's great that you're looking for ways to manage the stress and move forward in a positive way. Can you tell me a bit more about what specifically is causing you the most anxiety?

I'm really anxious about a past academic setback that could affect my opportunities for advanced education. It's been hard to shake off the worry as I try to focus on my future goals and personal growth.

It sounds like this academic setback has been really weighing on your mind, and it's totally understandable that it's causing you a lot of stress. It can be tough to move forward when you feel like something from your past is holding you back. But the fact that you're here, looking for ways to manage that stress and focus on your future goals, is a really positive step. Have you thought about any specific strategies for dealing with this anxiety, or are you looking for some suggestions?

I've been trying to manage this anxiety on my own but haven't come up with any effective strategies yet. I'm hoping you can suggest some ways to reduce this worry and help me focus on my future aspirations.

Absolutely, I'd be happy to provide some suggestions. One strategy that can be helpful in managing anxiety is mindfulness meditation. This involves focusing on your breath and being present in the moment, which can help to quiet the mind and reduce stress. There are many guided meditations available online that can help you get started. Would you be open to trying mindfulness meditation as a way to manage your anxiety?
Yes, I'm open to trying mindfulness meditation to help manage my anxiety. I believe it could assist in letting go of past worries and allow me to focus more clearly on my future goals.

Great! Mindfulness meditation can indeed be a powerful tool for managing anxiety and improving focus. I recommend starting with short sessions, perhaps 5-10 minutes a day, and gradually increasing the duration as you become more comfortable with the practice. It's important to be patient with yourself and remember that it's a skill that takes time to develop. As you begin incorporating mindfulness meditation into your routine, I'd like to hear about your experiences and discuss any challenges or successes you encounter. Would you be willing to share your progress with me in our next conversation?

Yes, I'm willing to share my progress with you in our next conversation. I believe tracking this practice will help me build resilience against my ongoing worries and keep me focused on moving forward with my plans.

That's a great mindset to have. As you embark on this mindfulness meditation journey, it's important to remember that consistency is key. It might be helpful to set a specific time each day for your practice, such as in the morning or before bed, to establish a routine. Additionally, there are apps and online resources that can support your practice by providing guided meditations and tracking your progress. Would you like me to suggest some of these resources for you to explore?

Yes, I'd appreciate suggestions for resources to support my mindfulness practice. I believe using them will help me maintain consistency and better manage my worries while focusing on my future aspirations.

It's been great working with you on addressing your concerns and finding strategies to manage your anxiety. To summarize, we've identified mindfulness meditation as a potential tool to help you cope with stress related to past academic setbacks and maintain focus on your future goals. As you begin this practice, remember to start with short sessions, be patient with yourself, and establish a consistent routine. Here are a few resources you might find helpful

1. Headspace - A popular mindfulness app offering guided meditations and mindfulness exercises.
2. Calm - Another app with a variety of meditation and relaxation resources, including guided meditations and soothing music.
3. Insight Timer - A free app with thousands of guided meditations and a community of users to connect with.

Please explore these resources and feel free to share your experiences and progress in our next conversation. Remember, managing anxiety is an ongoing process, and I'm here to support you along the way. Take care, and I look forward to our next chat.

Thank you for the resource suggestions I'll try them to help manage my worries about my past academic choices while staying focused on pursuing my master's. I look forward to sharing my progress next time.

I'm glad you found the suggestions helpful. It's been a productive conversation, and I'm happy we could identify strategies to help you manage your anxiety. Remember to be patient with yourself as you start your mindfulness meditation practice and explore the resources provided. I look forward to hearing about your progress during our next chat. Until then, take care and stay focused on your future aspirations.
Thank you for your encouragement I'll explore those resources to keep my anxiety in check as I work toward my master's goals. Take care until next time.

As you begin this practice, remember to start with short sessions, be patient with yourself, and establish a consistent routine. Here are a few resources you might find helpful

1. Headspace - A popular mindfulness app offering guided meditations and mindfulness exercises.
2. Calm - Another app with a variety of meditation and relaxation resources, including guided meditations and soothing music.
3. Insight Timer - A free app with thousands of guided meditations and a community of users to connect with.

Please explore these resources and feel free to share your experiences and progress in our next conversation. Remember, managing anxiety is an ongoing process, and I'm here to support you along the way. Take care, and I look forward to our next chat.
client: Thank you for the resource suggestions I'll try them to help manage my worries about my past academic choices while staying focused on pursuing my master's. I look forward to sharing my progress next time.
therapist: I'm glad you found the suggestions helpful. It's been a productive conversation, and I'm happy we could identify strategies to help you manage your anxiety. Remember to be patient with yourself as you start your mindfulness meditation practice and explore the resources provided. I look forward to hearing about your progress during our next chat. Until then, take care and stay focused on your future aspirations.
client: Thank you for your encouragement I'll explore those resources to keep my anxiety in check as I work toward my master's goals. Take care until next time.

concern: So I have a habit of getting nervous before a new semester begins the night before. How do you fellow college students deal with this? Especially if you are taking a class you feel super uneasy with but it’s required?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there, how are you doing today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen and support you however I can.
I'm doing okay, but I'm feeling a bit anxious about the upcoming semester. Yes, I'd like to discuss some strategies for managing that uneasiness with required classes.

It's completely understandable to feel anxious about a new semester, especially when there are required classes that you may not be looking forward to. Let's explore those feelings together and see if we can come up with some strategies to help ease your anxiety. Can you tell me a bit more about what specifically is causing your uneasiness with these classes?
I'm mostly nervous about the uncertainty of handling required classes that feel overwhelming. It's the anticipation of the semester's demands that heightens my anxiety.

It sounds like the unknowns of the upcoming semester, especially with required classes, are causing you a lot of stress. It's natural to feel anxious when facing uncertainty, but remember that you've likely handled similar challenges before. Perhaps we can focus on building up your confidence and self-efficacy to help you feel more prepared for the semester ahead. Would you be open to discussing some strategies for breaking down these classes into more manageable pieces?
Yes, I'm open to discussing strategies for breaking down these classes. It might help me feel more in control and less overwhelmed as the semester approaches.

Great! One approach could be to create a detailed study plan for each class, outlining specific tasks and deadlines. This can help you visualize the work ahead and make it feel more manageable. Additionally, you could explore forming study groups or finding a study partner to share the workload and provide mutual support. How do these ideas sound to you, and do you have any initial thoughts on how you might implement them?

I think these ideas sound practical and could help ease my nervousness about managing required classes. For implementation, I might begin by outlining a weekly study plan to make the workload feel more approachable.

That's a great first step! When you sit down to create your weekly study plan, consider setting aside some extra time to review class materials, take notes, or work on assignments. This can help build in some flexibility and alleviate pressure if unexpected challenges arise. Additionally, you could try scheduling regular breaks and self-care activities to help maintain a healthy balance and prevent burnout. How does this sound, and would you like to discuss any other strategies to help you feel more prepared?

This sounds helpful for managing my anxiety by adding flexibility and self-care to my plans, which could make the semester feel less daunting. Yes, I'd like to discuss other strategies to further prepare me for those uneasy required classes.

One additional strategy could be to connect with your professors or teaching assistants during their office hours to discuss your concerns and seek guidance on course expectations. They might offer valuable insights and resources to help you navigate the challenging aspects of the classes. Would you feel comfortable reaching out to them, and if so, what questions or topics would you like to address during these conversations?

I feel somewhat comfortable reaching out to professors or TAs, even though it adds to my pre-semester jitters. I'd like to ask about key course expectations and practical tips for handling the challenging material in those required classes.

It's great that you're considering reaching out to your professors and TAs. Remember, they are there to support your learning journey and help you succeed. To make the most of your conversations with them, prepare your questions in advance and take notes during the discussion. This will not only demonstrate your commitment to the course but also provide you with a helpful reference as you navigate the semester. Good luck, and remember to be kind to yourself throughout this process. Let's plan to follow up in a month to discuss your progress and any additional support you may need.
Thank you for the advice I'll prepare for those conversations to ease my pre-semester nerves and handle the required classes better. I'm looking forward to our follow-up in a month.

concern:
So I'm a first gen, and I have no idea what half the terms I find when looking up college information mean, and I find myself lost more often than not. Other than my family I have no real connections, and the only person that went to college in my family is my brother who quit part way through and is stuck with student loans. Is there anywhere I can go for help?

There's also something specific that just confuses and stuns me. Most help or scholarships I've found involve previous experience with community service or an essay about how you plan to make a difference. I don't plan on making a difference man, I just want to learn how to do what I love so I don't end up in a soul sucking dead end job. I just want to make character design and video games for a living, I'm not looking to help some group or anything, I just want a decent job and life.

I dunno I'm just confused about all this, I just wanna learn man.

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're having a tough time. Would you like to share what's been going on?
Yes, I'd like to share a bit. I'm feeling overwhelmed as a first-gen student trying to navigate college resources and opportunities.

It can definitely be tough to navigate college resources and opportunities, especially as a first-gen student. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. Is there anything in particular that's been especially challenging for you?

I'm finding the requirements for scholarships and opportunities particularly challenging, as they often feel misaligned with my goals. It's been tough not knowing where to turn for straightforward guidance as a first-gen student.

It's definitely frustrating when you feel like the resources available don't align with your goals. It's great that you're seeking guidance, and I can see why it might be tough to find that as a first-gen student. Have you considered reaching out to your school's counseling or advising services? They might be able to provide some direction or connect you with other resources.

Yes, I've considered reaching out to advising services, but as a first-gen student, I'm still unsure how to effectively use them. I just need some simple guidance to navigate college without the added pressures.

It seems like you're caught in a tough spot, wanting to make the most of your college experience but feeling unsure about where to find straightforward guidance. It's clear that these concerns are causing you stress, and it's important to address them. Would you be open to discussing some possible first steps in seeking support from advising services or other resources?
Yes, I'm open to discussing some first steps for seeking support from advising services. I just need clear, simple direction to navigate college without the extra pressures.

It's great that you're open to discussing first steps. One initial action could be reaching out to your school's advising services and expressing your concerns as a first-gen student. You can ask them about any resources or workshops specifically tailored to first-gen students. Additionally, consider preparing a list of specific questions or concerns you have about your scholarship requirements and navigating college resources. This way, you'll have a clear direction when you connect with the advising services. How does that sound?

That sounds helpful for getting started, as it aligns with my need for straightforward guidance as a first-gen student. I'm ready to try preparing a list to make the most of advising services without overwhelming myself.

Great, it's encouraging to see your willingness to take that first step. As you prepare your list, consider prioritizing the questions or concerns that have been causing you the most stress. This way, you can address the most pressing issues first and build momentum in navigating these challenges. Is there a specific time you plan to start working on your list, perhaps today or tomorrow?
I plan to start working on my list today, as that feels manageable and keeps things straightforward for me. This will help me focus on the essentials without overwhelming myself right away.

It's wonderful that you're taking initiative and starting on your list today. Remember to prioritize your concerns and focus on one step at a time to avoid feeling overwhelmed. Best of luck, and feel free to reach out again if you need further support.
Thanks for the support I'll get started on that list today to keep things simple and focus on learning what I need for my future in game design. Take care.

It's been great discussing your concerns today, and I'm glad we could identify a practical first step for you to take. Remember to stay focused on your priorities and take things one step at a time. I wish you all the best in your college journey, and please don't hesitate to reach out again if you need further assistance. Good luck, and take care!
Thanks for the guidance I'll keep it simple and focus on figuring out the basics so I can pursue game design without getting overwhelmed. Take care!

concern:
I was speaking to a class friend the other day and at some point she brought up that she hates when individual students "hog" the study rooms when it should only be groups in there. At my campus, the policy is that individuals are allowed to use them, but groups of 2 or more are also allowed to (politely) kick them out if they need the space. These rules are posted pretty clearly in front of each room, so I didn't really understand her complaint... they're not hogging it, you could just ask them for the room.

I often do this as an individual (didn't tell her that though), but I recognize a lot of people are shy, have social anxiety, or they feel bad about kicking someone out. So one hand I feel bad since I might be the reason some people can't get a room, but on the other hand I don't feel like that's necessarily my fault. Thoughts?

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! How's your day going so far? Anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about?

My day has been okay, but I've been feeling a bit uneasy about some social situations on campus. I'd like to discuss some internal conflicts I'm having around group spaces and personal responsibilities.

Sounds like there's a lot going on in your head. Navigating social situations can be tricky, and it's great that you're reaching out to talk about it. Do you mind sharing more about these group spaces and personal responsibilities that are causing some internal conflicts?

I've been grappling with internal conflicts about using shared group spaces individually, which makes me feel torn between my own needs and considering others' potential discomfort. This involves weighing personal responsibilities against the broader social implications of such spaces.

It's understandable that you're feeling conflicted between your needs and the potential impact on others. It can be challenging to find a balance between taking care of yourself and being considerate of those around you. Have you thought about any possible ways to address this situation that could help you feel more at ease while also respecting others' comfort?

I've thought about alternatives like seeking out less contested spaces when possible, to avoid contributing to others' discomfort. Still, I struggle with finding a fair balance between my personal needs and being considerate of the group's dynamics.

It seems like you've been putting a lot of effort into finding a solution that works for everyone. It's important to remember that your needs matter too, and it's okay to prioritize them while still being mindful of others. Have you considered discussing your concerns with the group to find a compromise that works for everyone?

I've thought about discussing my concerns with the group, but I'm hesitant due to potential discomfort it might cause for everyone involved. Still, I'm trying to find ways to balance my own needs while being mindful of the group's overall dynamics.

It's natural to feel hesitant about bringing up concerns that might cause discomfort. However, open communication can often lead to better understanding and solutions that work for everyone. Is there a way you could approach the conversation that might make it feel safer for you and the group to discuss these issues?

I could try starting the conversation in a low-pressure setting, like a casual group chat, to make it feel less confrontational for everyone. However, I'm still weighing how to express my needs without making others feel guilty about the shared space.

That sounds like a great first step. Perhaps you could frame the conversation around finding a balance that benefits everyone, emphasizing that your goal is to create a comfortable environment for both yourself and the group. By focusing on the collective well-being, you can address your needs while minimizing the potential for others to feel guilty or singled out.
I'll consider framing my thoughts around group benefits to keep things positive. This approach might help me address my own discomfort without making the discussion feel accusatory.

When you feel ready to initiate the conversation, it might be helpful to prepare some talking points to keep the discussion focused and productive. Would you like to brainstorm some key ideas to include in your message to the group?
Yes, I'd like to brainstorm some key ideas for the message. Focusing on shared benefits and mutual respect could help ensure the discussion promotes a comfortable space for everyone involved.

It's great that you're considering a thoughtful approach to address your concerns with the group. Remember to focus on shared respect and benefits when initiating the conversation. When you're ready, you can reach out to the group and express your thoughts. Feel free to reach out again if you'd like to discuss this further or have any additional concerns. Take care!
I'll take your advice and focus on shared benefits when discussing study room etiquette, ensuring it promotes respect for both individuals and groups. Thanks for the supporttake care!

concern: I have a friend who I was planning on getting an apartment with next year, but they mentioned wanting a 12-month lease when I would only want 9. Are there situations where we could still be roommates, or would it just not work out?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and offer support. What's on your mind today?
I'm dealing with a potential conflict in my housing plans with a friend, and it's making me unsure about our friendship. I'm hoping to get some guidance on how to approach this.

It sounds like you're in a tough spot, navigating both a potential housing conflict and concerns about your friendship. It's understandable to feel unsure in this situation. Can you tell me more about what's happening with your housing plans?

I'm having a disagreement with my friend about the length of our potential apartment lease, which is making me question if we can make it work as roommates. I'm worried this could affect our friendship and am looking for advice on how to discuss it.

It's tough when practical decisions like housing plans overlap with relationships. It's important to approach this conversation with your friend openly and honestly. Have you tried expressing your concerns about the lease length to your friend?
I've brought up my preference for a shorter lease, but I haven't fully discussed how it's making me anxious about our friendship. I'm seeking advice on how to have that conversation effectively.

It's great that you've initiated the conversation about your preference for a shorter lease. It shows that you value open communication in your friendship. To address your concerns about the impact on your friendship, consider these steps

1. Choose a suitable time and place to have the conversation, ensuring you both have the space to discuss your feelings openly.
2. Begin by reaffirming your appreciation for your friendship and your desire to maintain it.
3. Share your anxieties about the potential conflict, emphasizing that you want to work together to find a solution that works for both of you.
4. Be open to listening to your friend's perspective and concerns, as they may have valid reasons for their preferences.
5. Together, explore possible compromises or alternatives that could address both of your concerns and priorities.

Remember, it's essential to approach the conversation with empathy, understanding, and a willingness to collaborate on a solution. By doing so, you can navigate this challenge while preserving and potentially strengthening your friendship.
I appreciate the steps you've outlined for handling this discussion they make me feel more prepared. I'll work on choosing the right time to talk and emphasize our friendship to keep things positive.

It's good to hear that you feel more prepared for the conversation. Remember to be patient with yourself and your friend as you work through this situation together. It's natural to have different perspectives, and open communication can help you find common ground. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss or any other concerns you have about the upcoming conversation?
I don't have any other concerns right now, but I'm still a bit nervous about ensuring the discussion goes smoothly. I'm committed to following your advice to keep things positive and collaborative.

It's completely understandable to feel nervous about having a sensitive conversation with a friend. Remember that your intention is to preserve the friendship and find a solution that works for both of you. As you prepare for the discussion, keep these additional tips in mind

1. Use "I" statements to express your feelings and concerns. This helps avoid placing blame and encourages open communication.
2. Be mindful of your tone and body language, as they can significantly impact the overall atmosphere of the conversation.
3. Take deep breaths and remind yourself that you're both working together to find a solution. This can help ease any anxiety you may have.
4. If emotions run high during the conversation, it's okay to take a break and revisit the discussion when both of you have had time to process your feelings.

By focusing on empathy, understanding, and collaboration, you'll be better equipped to navigate this conversation and maintain a strong, healthy friendship.

I appreciate the additional tips on handling the conversation they'll help me focus on maintaining a positive dynamic with my friend. I'm feeling more equipped now to approach the discussion with empathy and keep things collaborative.

It's great to hear that you're feeling more prepared and confident in approaching this conversation. Remember that open and honest communication is key to maintaining a healthy friendship, and it's important to be understanding of each other's perspectives. Would you like to summarize your plan for the discussion to ensure you feel ready?
Yes, I'd like to summarize my plan briefly. I'll start by sharing my feelings using 'I' statements, stay mindful of my tone, and focus on finding a mutual solution that respects both our needs.

It sounds like you have a solid plan in place for your conversation with your friend. By using "I" statements, being mindful of your tone, and working together to find a solution, you'll be fostering open communication and understanding. I'm confident that your approach will help maintain your strong friendship. Remember that it's okay to take breaks if needed and to be patient with each other. Good luck, and feel free to reach out again if you need any further guidance.
Thanks for your guidance I'll go ahead and talk to my friend about the lease using this approach to keep our friendship strong. Take care!

client: I appreciate the additional tips on handling the conversation they'll help me focus on maintaining a positive dynamic with my friend. I'm feeling more equipped now to approach the discussion with empathy and keep things collaborative.
therapist: It's great to hear that you're feeling more prepared and confident in approaching this conversation. Remember that open and honest communication is key to maintaining a healthy friendship, and it's important to be understanding of each other's perspectives. Would you like to summarize your plan for the discussion to ensure you feel ready?
client: Yes, I'd like to summarize my plan briefly. I'll start by sharing my feelings using 'I' statements, stay mindful of my tone, and focus on finding a mutual solution that respects both our needs.
therapist: It sounds like you have a solid plan in place for your conversation with your friend. By using "I" statements, being mindful of your tone, and working together to find a solution, you'll be fostering open communication and understanding. I'm confident that your approach will help maintain your strong friendship. Remember that it's okay to take breaks if needed and to be patient with each other. Good luck, and feel free to reach out again if you need any further guidance.
client: Thanks for your guidance I'll go ahead and talk to my friend about the lease using this approach to keep our friendship strong. Take care!

concern: Can I got to my old city community college and ask for help on transferring to university even if I already graduated from that same city community college a year ago? I didnt enroll into their transfer program even if it was offered to me and I feel I made a mistake. I want to continue school but I only have an associates in general studies.

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! Is there something on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen and support you however I can.
Yes, I've been feeling uncertain about my educational decisions and how to move forward with my studies. I'm hoping to explore ways to address that regret and plan my next steps.

Uncertainty about your education can be tough, especially when youre trying to plan your future. Lets start by digging a little deeper into whats causing these feelings of regret. Can you share a bit more about what specifically youre regretting?

I'm regretting not taking advantage of certain opportunities during my community college experience that could have helped me advance my education. This has left me feeling stuck and unsure about how to proceed with my studies now.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck because you feel like you missed out on opportunities that could have helped you progress in your education. It's completely normal to feel regret in situations like this. But remember, it's never too late to explore new options and make a plan for moving forward. What kind of opportunities are you wishing you had taken advantage of?

I'm regretting not pursuing certain academic pathways that were available to me at the time, which might have smoothed my transition to further education. This has made me feel hesitant about exploring new options now, but I'm eager to figure out how to get back on track.

It's great that you're eager to find new ways to move forward. Recognizing past missed opportunities can be a valuable learning experience, and it's important to remember that you still have the power to shape your educational journey. Let's explore what new options might be available to you now that can help you achieve your goals. Can you tell me more about the academic pathways you're interested in?
I'm interested in transfer pathways to four-year universities that can build on my associate's degree. Exploring these now feels like a way to address my regrets and move forward with my education.

It's great that you're considering transfer pathways to four-year universities as a way to build upon your associate's degree. Taking actionable steps can help you regain a sense of control and progress in your educational journey. Would you like to start by researching potential universities and their transfer requirements, or would you prefer to seek guidance from an academic advisor to better understand your options?

I think seeking guidance from an academic advisor would be the best first step to understand my options clearly. This way, I can start addressing my past regrets and make informed decisions to advance my education.

That's a great plan! Seeking guidance from an academic advisor can provide valuable insights and help you make informed decisions about your education. Remember to prepare any questions or concerns you may have before meeting with the advisor. I wish you the best of luck, and feel free to reach out again if you need any further assistance.
Thanks for your guidanceI'll reach out to an academic advisor soon to explore transfer options and build on my associate's degree. I appreciate the support.

I'm glad we could work together to identify a plan of action to address your concerns. Remember, it's important to learn from past experiences and use them as stepping stones for future growth. Best of luck with your academic advisor meeting, and don't hesitate to reach out again if you need further support.
Thanks for the encouragementI'll reach out to the academic advisor soon to figure out my transfer options and build on my associate's degree.

It's great to see you taking proactive steps towards addressing your concerns and moving forward with your education. Remember to approach the meeting with an open mind and be prepared to explore various options that may be available to you. Good luck, and keep in mind that you can always seek further support if needed.
Thanks for the advice. I'll reach out to the academic advisor soon to see about transferring with my associate's degree.

It's been a productive session, and I'm glad we could identify a plan to help you address your concerns. Remember to focus on the future and use past experiences as opportunities for growth. Good luck with your meeting, and feel free to reach out again if you need further support.
Thanks for your support. I'll contact the academic advisor soon to explore transferring with my associate's degree.

To summarize our session, we discussed your concerns about educational decisions and regret over missed opportunities. We explored new academic pathways and transfer options to four-year universities. As a next step, you'll contact an academic advisor to discuss transferring with your associate's degree. Remember to approach the meeting with an open mind and focus on future growth. Good luck, and feel free to reach out again if you need further support.
I appreciate your guidance on my transfer concerns. I'll reach out to the academic advisor soon to discuss my options with my associate's degree.
